THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Shirley Towne, Appellant,
      
    
  


  v.
  
    
      
        
          State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, State Farm Fire and Casualty Company, Hank Gaddis, Bernard Stanley, and Clean It, Inc., d/b/a Pro Clean, Defendants,
          of whom State Farm Fire and Casualty Company are Respondents.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-255
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed April 7, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Todd Raymond Ellis, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Robert McKenzie, and Gary H. Johnson, II, both of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this civil action, Shirley Towne appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) in favor of State Farm Fire and Casualty Company, arguing the circuit court erred in holding judicial estoppel precluded Towneâ€™s argument to the jury.Â  We reverse.
FACTS

In November 1999, a van driven by Bernard Stanley crossed the roadwayâ€™s center line and hit a vehicle driven by Towne, causing her to suffer various injuries.Â  In November 2001, Towne initiated this action claiming personal injury and defamation.Â  In her complaint, Towne asserted Clean It, Inc., doing business as Pro Clean, owned the van driven by Stanley.Â  Pro Clean filed an answer admitting ownership of the vehicle driven by Stanley and admitting the accident occurred while Stanley was acting within the course and scope of his employment with Pro Clean.Â  State Farm filed an answer and counterclaim, questioning whether its commercial liability policy issued to Pro Clean provided coverage for the accident.Â  
In December 2001, State Farm proposed a settlement, offering Towne the limits of Pro Cleanâ€™s liability policy as well as Towneâ€™s underinsured motorist coverage.[1]Â  Towne accepted the settlement and executed a covenant and agreement not to execute in consideration for the payment of the limits of Pro Cleanâ€™s policy in the amount of $100,000.00.Â  Towne also obtained payment of an additional $100,000.00 from her underinsured motorist carrier in exchange for a policy release.Â  In executing both settlement agreements, Towne made certain factual representations, including the assertion that the vehicle operated by Stanley was owned by Pro Clean.Â  The covenant and agreement not to execute and the policy release made no assertions or representations that the vehicle driven by Stanley was owned or â€œnon-ownedâ€ under State Farmâ€™s commercial liability policy issued to Pro Clean.Â  Towne specifically reserved the right to pursue recovery in the settlement documents under the commercial liability policy and that was the sole issue for consideration in State Farmâ€™s declaratory judgment action.
When the declaratory judgment action proceeded to trial, Towne argued the vehicle driven by Stanley in the accident constituted a â€œnon-ownedâ€ vehicle under the definition provided in State Farmâ€™s commercial liability policy issued to Pro Clean.Â  State Farm moved for a directed verdict based on judicial estoppel, arguing that Towne was precluded from asserting the vehicle was â€œnon-ownedâ€ under the commercial liability policy because she had previously asserted that Pro Clean owned the vehicle.Â  The circuit court denied the motion, holding judicial estoppel was inapplicable to this action because Towne had not persuaded a court to accept her earlier position regarding ownership of the vehicle and was not attempting to mislead the court with a new position.Â  The issue was submitted to the jury, which found the vehicle to be â€œnon-ownedâ€ under the definition found in the policy.Â  State Farm moved for JNOV, arguing Towne should be judicially estopped from arguing the â€œnon-ownedâ€ vehicle exception to the jury because she had previously asserted that Pro Clean owned the vehicle involved in the accident.Â  The motion was granted by the circuit court.Â  Towne timely appealed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW

 In ruling on a motion for JNOV, the trial judge should not disturb the factual findings of a jury unless a review of the record discloses no evidence that reasonably supports them.Â  Horry County v. Laychur, 315 S.C. 364, 367, 434 S.E.2d 259, 261 (1993).Â  â€œThe jury verdict will be upheld if there is any evidence to sustain the factual findings implicit in the juryâ€™s verdict.â€Â  Shupe v. Settle, 315 S.C. 510, 515, 445 S.E.2d 651, 654 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  In making this determination, the judge must view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Gilliland v. Doe, 357 S.C. 197, 199, 592 S.E.2d 626, 627 (2004).Â  The trial court is concerned with the existence of evidence, not its weight.Â  Curcio v. Caterpillar, Inc., 355 S.C. 316, 320, 585 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2003).Â  The trial judge must deny the motion when the evidence yields more than one inference or its inferences are in doubt.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003).Â  
â€œWhen considering the motion, neither this court nor the trial court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony and evidence.â€Â  Reiland v. Southland Equipment Service, Inc., 330 S.C. 617, 634, 500 S.E.2d 145, 154 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  We will reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling on a JNOV motion only when there is no evidence to support the ruling or where the ruling is controlled by an error of law.Â  Hinkle v. Natâ€™l Cas. Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 92, 96, 579 S.E.2d 616, 618 (2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Judicial Estoppel
Towne asserts the trial court erred in granting State Farmâ€™s motion for JNOV in finding judicial estoppel precluded Towne from taking the position argued to the jury.Â  We agree.
Judicial estoppel is an equitable concept that prevents a litigant from asserting a position inconsistent with, or in conflict with, one the litigant has previously asserted in the same or a related proceeding.Â  Hayne Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 251, 489 S.E.2d 472, 477 (1997).Â  Judicial estoppel as an equitable concept is a discretionary doctrine and should be applied sparingly with clear regard for the facts of the particular case.Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, 342 S.C. 352, 368, 536 S.E.2d 698, 706 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The application of judicial estoppel must be determined on a case-by-case basis, and must not be applied to impede the truth-seeking function of the court.Â  Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 83-84, 552 S.E.2d 767, 772 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The purpose of the doctrine is to ensure the integrity of the judicial process, and to prevent manipulation of the judicial system by the litigants.Â  Quinn v. Sharon Corp., 343 S.C. 411, 414, 540 S.E.2d 474, 475 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
In Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 83, 552 S.E.2d 767, 772 (Ct. App. 2001), this court provided the following general guidelines for the doctrine of judicial estoppel to apply: (1) two inconsistent positions taken by the same party or parties in privity with one another; (2) the positions must be taken in the same or related proceedings involving the same party or parties in privity with each other; (3) the party taking the position must have been successful in maintaining that position and have received some benefit; (4) the inconsistency must be part of an intentional effort to mislead the court; and (5) the two positions must be totally inconsistent.Â  Recently, in Cothran v. Brown, 357 S.C. 210, 215-16, 592 S.E.2d 629, 632 (2004), our supreme court reaffirmed the Carrigg guidelines, holding them to be necessary elements for the doctrine of judicial estoppel to apply.
The evidence in this matter fails to satisfy the fourth necessary element of judicial estoppel.Â  The Cothran court held, as an element of judicial estoppel, the inconsistency must be part of an intentional effort to mislead the court.Â  Id. at 215-16, 592 S.E.2d at 632.Â  We find no evidence Towne sought to intentionally mislead the trial court.Â  To the contrary, the issue advanced to the jury in the declaratory judgment action was whether the vehicle involved in the accident qualified as a â€œnon-ownedâ€ vehicle under the definition provided in State Farmâ€™s commercial liability policy.Â  An assertion of ownership made by Towne in pleadings or in settlement documents does not preclude adjudication of that separate contract issue, nor does it preclude a finding that the vehicle qualified under the definition found in the policy.Â  Therefore, there was no intentional effort to mislead the court by Towne and without an intentional effort to mislead the court judicial estoppel cannot apply.
II.Â  Additional Sustaining Grounds
State Farm advances three additional sustaining grounds to allow this court to affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant of JNOV in the event we find judicial estoppel inapplicable to the facts of this case.Â  Essentially, State Farm alleges Towne should be judicially bound by her pleadings.Â  We find this argument to be without merit.Â  
We hold any representations made by Towne in her pleadings in regard to the ownership of the vehicle involved in the accident are separate and distinct from the issue of whether the vehicle constitutes an exception to the â€œnon-ownedâ€ vehicle coverage afforded in State Farmâ€™s commercial liability policy issued to Pro Clean.Â  Therefore, any representations made by Towne in her pleadings have no bearing on whether the vehicle constitutes a â€œnon-ownedâ€ vehicle under the definition found in the commercial liability policy and do not judicially bind Towne in the declaratory judgment action.
REVERSED. 
ANDERSON, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] State Farm provided insurance both to Towne as underinsured motorist coverage and Pro Clean as liability coverage and a commercial liability policy.

          Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, and Ernest Charles Grose, Jr., of Greenwood, for Appellant.
          Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor William Townes Jones, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  PER CURIAM: This appeal arises from the conviction of Terrence Edwards for charges related to the death of Jonathan Blackston.Â  Edwards complains the State made statements during his trial that were inconsistent with those made by the State during a co-defendantâ€™s plea hearing.Â  Additionally, he argues prejudicial evidence should have been excluded.Â  We affirm. 
  FACTS  
  Terrence Edwards and Sergio Marshall were indicted for the offenses of murder, armed robbery, grand larceny of a vehicle, possession of a pistol by a person less than twenty-one years of age, and possession of a firearm or knife during the commission of a violent crime.Â  All of the charges arose from the shooting of Jonathan Blackston.
Marshall pled guilty to all of the charges and was sentenced to a total of thirty-five years imprisonment.Â  Subsequently, the case against Edwards went to trial.Â  The jury found against Edwards on all counts.Â  The court sentenced Edwards to thirty years imprisonment for murder, twenty-five years consecutive for armed robbery, and five years concurrent on each of the charges of grand larceny of a vehicle, possession of a pistol by a person under the age of twenty-one years of age, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  
  â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  â€œThis Court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€Â  Id. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  
  LAW AND DISCUSSION
  
  I.   Collateral and Judicial Estoppel
  Edwards appeals his conviction, arguing the State pursued theories against him and Marshall that were inconsistent and should have been barred by collateral and judicial estoppel.Â  We disagree.Â  
  South Carolina courts have not specifically addressed the applicability of collateral or judicial estoppel in criminal prosecution.Â  The United States Supreme Court has recognized that collateral estoppel may be applied in cases of federal criminal law.Â  Ashe v. Swenson, 397 U.S. 436, 443-44 (1970).Â  Collateral estoppel in practice â€œsimply means that when an issue of ultimate fact has once been determined by a valid and final judgment, that issue cannot be litigated between the same parties in any future lawsuit.â€Â  Id. at 443.Â  
  We have adopted a rule for determining whether a party in South Carolina is precluded from relitigating an issue with a nonparty.Â  â€œ[T]o assert collateral estoppel successfully, the party seeking issue preclusion still must show that the issue was actually litigated and directly determined in the prior action and that the matter or fact directly in issue was necessary to support the first judgment.â€ Beall v. Doe, 281 S.C. 363, 371, 315 S.E.2d 186, 191 (Ct. App. 1984).
  â€œJudicial estoppel precludes a party from adopting a position in conflict with one earlier taken in the same or related litigation.â€Â  Hayne Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 251, 489 S.E.2d 472, 477 (1997).Â  The doctrine exists to protect the integrity of the judicial process and courts rather than to protect litigants from allegedly improper or deceitful conduct by their adversaries. Id.Â  The supreme court has stated the following elements are necessary for the doctrine of judicial estoppel to apply: (1) two inconsistent positions taken by the same party or parties in privity with one another; (2) the positions must be taken in the same or related proceedings involving the same party or parties in privity with each other; (3) the party taking the position must have been successful in maintaining that position and have received some benefit; (4) the inconsistency must be part of an intentional effort to mislead the court; and (5) the two positions must be totally inconsistent.Â  Cothran v. Brown, 357 S.C. 210, 215-216, 592 S.E.2d 629, 632 (2004).
  Importantly, a threshold determination in any discussion of the applicability of either collateral or judicial estoppel is that two inconsistent statements were made.Â  To determine this, the court must examine the exact language used at Marshallâ€™s plea hearing and Edwardsâ€™ trial.Â  
  Chief Sheriffâ€™s Deputy Marion Johnson and Solicitor Townes Jones provided the factual predicate for the crime against Marshall.Â  Johnson began by explaining:
  
    Marshall . . . kind of held back on us, wouldnâ€™t tell us anything . . . .Â  He did come forward and admitted to shooting â€“ the defendant admitted to shooting . . . the victim . . . .Â  There were two gunshot wounds to the body, one to the arm and the other to the back of the head.Â  There was also blunt trauma around the chest and arms and the rest of the body. . . .Â  They also did take a wallet from the pocket of Mr. Blackston which contained about one hundred and fifteen dollars, and they split the money up and went to the Anderson County Fair . . . .
  
  Next, the court asked about Marshallâ€™s motive.Â  Johnson replied, â€œFrom what Mr. Edwards states and the best we can determine they were out there, and they were rolling up a joint . . . and for some reason Mr. Marshall was the one that actually shot Mr. Blackston.â€Â  
  Solicitor Jones then interrupted and stated: 
  
    [R]elying solely on the evidence that we would be prepared to present at trial in this case, you know, we would have presented to the jury that this defendant and the victim were together alone, they were acquaintances, and they had no prior evidence of a significant problem or threat to do bodily harm to either prior (sic) to this occasion.Â  But . . . there were verbal disagreements or verbal remarks between the two that one could surmise and conclude amounted to a kind of machismo standoff . . . .Â  [A]nd unfortunately a relationship that on the surface appeared to be one that involved friendship turned quickly, abruptly deadly.Â  That would be our argument.
  
  The solicitor continued regarding motive: 
  
    We would not be able to argue that we had evidence to show that there was a conspiracy or that there was any plan and intent to commit this robbery, but nevertheless, the fact that it was conducted in conjunction with the murder in our opinion would give rise to argue at least that it was in the mind of the murderer.
  
  And concluded, â€œ[W]hat I have presented to you would have been the argument that we would have made from the facts that we felt we would have had at trial.â€ 
  Later, at Edwardsâ€™ trial, the solicitor in his closing statement explained the shooting might have begun as a robbery, but if Blackston refused, â€œMr. Gunman says enough of that, pop.â€Â  The solicitor continued by saying, â€œAssuming that Sergio was the shooter,â€ Edwards â€œhelped him move the body,â€ â€œget away from the scene,â€ they gave each other an alibi, and â€œaid[ed] and abet[ted] each other.â€Â  
  Edwards argues the State suggested he was the gunman in the closing statement whereas the factual predicate in the Marshall plea shows the Stateâ€™s understanding and theory was that Marshall was the gunman.Â Â  
  After a careful review of the record, we cannot determine the solicitorâ€™s comment that â€œMr. Gunman says enough of that, pop,â€ constitutes a suggestion Edwards was the gunman.Â  Edwards seeks to pair this language with the solicitorâ€™s comments on Edwardsâ€™ claim he was just an accessory after the fact with regards to the robbery charge.Â  The solicitor did ridicule such a claim, characterizing Edwardsâ€™ counselâ€™s argument as, â€œHeâ€™s going to try to tell you what I did for [Marshall] was dumb.Â  It was dumb and it was, uh, letâ€™s see, accessory after the fact.Â  He was already shot and dead, and Terrence came along and helped him afterwards, or he was already robbing him and Terrence just kind of helped him afterwards, kind of.â€Â  The solicitor did anticipate and attack the arguments likely to be advanced on behalf of Edwards, but we do not see how that attack contradicts the Stateâ€™s comments at Marshallâ€™s plea hearing.
  In examining the transcript from the plea hearing, the only comment that gives the court pause is the solicitorâ€™s statement that â€œrelying solely on the evidence that we would be prepared to present at trial in this case . . . we would have presented to the jury that this defendant and the victim were together alone, . . .Â  [and the] friendship turned quickly, abruptly deadly.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The solicitorâ€™s use of the word â€œaloneâ€ is the linchpin of Edwardsâ€™ case.Â  However, when read against the full explanation that had just been provided to the court by Johnson, it is not enough.Â  Johnsonâ€™s explanation clearly showed that another person, Edwards, was present and a co-defendant in this case.Â  As such, any reliance on the term â€œaloneâ€ is mitigated by the fuller explanation provided to the court by the State.Â  Just as a court cannot view a term in isolation when interpreting a statute or contract, or determining whether a jury charge is in error, we will not wrench from context a comment made by the solicitor in this case.Â  See e.g. Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495-96, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).
  After a careful reading of the Stateâ€™s explanation of the case in the Marshall plea hearing and the Stateâ€™s arguments at trial, we find no inconsistent position.Â  We specifically decline to address South Carolinaâ€™s adoption of either collateral estoppel or judicial estoppel in the criminal context, and instead hold that neither would apply because there was no inconsistency between the solicitorâ€™s positions.
  II.   Admission of statement by Edwards
  Edwards also argues a statement he made to police was so prejudicial that it should not have been admitted into evidence.Â  We disagree.
  Edwards argues the court erred in admitting his statement: â€œSergio and I had joked before about robbing somebody.â€Â  He asserts it should have been excluded because the State was collaterally and judicially estopped from trying to make a planned robbery an issue based on its assertions at Marshallâ€™s plea hearing.Â  Edwards also argues the probative value of the evidence was substantially outweighed by its prejudicial effect.Â  We disagree.
  After asserting that the State was barred from entering this evidence based on collateral and judicial estoppel, Edwards does not address this issue in the body of his argument.Â  In Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Partnership, 312 S.C. 102, 439 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 1993), this court found an issue was abandoned on appeal when the parties raised the issue in their statement of appeal but did not argue it in their brief.Â  Id. at 106, 439 S.E.2d at 285.Â  We similarly find Edwards has abandoned this issue on appeal because he has not discussed it in his brief.
  However, even if we were to consider the issue on appeal, we would determine that neither collateral nor judicial estoppel barred the introduction of the evidence that Marshall and Edwards joked about committing a robbery.Â  The Stateâ€™s explanation of the crime at Marshallâ€™s plea hearing was that:
  
    We would not be able to argue that we had evidence to show that there was a conspiracy or that there was any plan and intent to commit this robbery, but nevertheless, the fact that it was conducted in conjunction with the murder in our opinion would give rise to argue at least that it was in the mind of the murderer. 
  
  This statement is at best inconclusive and unclear.Â  It admits the State did not have admissible evidence of a conspiracy to commit a robbery while also maintaining its commission in conjunction with the murder suggests it was in Marshallâ€™s mind.Â  The explanation that the State could not prove a conspiracy to commit robbery should not prevent introduction of the portion of the statement discussing the joking reference to robbing someone.
  Edwards also argues the statement should have been excluded because it was overly prejudicial.Â  Rule 403, SCRE, says otherwise admissible evidence â€œmay be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice . . . .â€Â  â€œUnfair prejudice means an undue tendency to suggest a decision on an improper basis.â€Â  Kennedy v. Griffin, 358 S.C. 122, 127, 595 S.E.2d 248, 250 (Ct. App. 2004). 
  â€œA trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in â€˜exceptional circumstances.â€™â€Â  State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 357, 543 S.E.2d 586, 593 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œWe review a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding Rule 403 pursuant to the abuse of discretion standard and are obligated to give great deference to the trial courtâ€™s judgment.â€Â  State v. Myers, 359 S.C. 40, 48, 596 S.E.2d 488, 492 (2004). 
  Because the testimony was that Edwards was at the scene of the crime, the joke was relevant to show he was acting in unison with Marshall.Â  Although the joke was certainly prejudicial, we also find it relevant.Â  We note the admission of the joke did not prevent Edwards from presenting a defense that he was merely present and not involved with the shooting.Â  In fact, this appears to have been the ultimate strategy of trial counsel.Â  It resulted in charges by the judge on mere presence and â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all.â€Â  We cannot determine that the testimony engendered any undue tendency in the jury to reach a verdict of guilty solely or even primarily on this evidence.Â  Therefore, we find the trial court did not abuse his discretion by allowing the testimony into evidence.
  AFFIRMED.
  ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Haas v. Haas
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
W.V. Haas, Jr., (Individually and as Trustee), Appellant,
v.
John E. Haas, Susan K.H. Betenbaugh, (Individually and as Trustees), Stephen D. Gillespie, Laura G. Greer, and David V.
Betenbaugh,
Of whom John E. Haas and Susan K.H. Betenbaugh are the,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-273
Heard March 9, 2005 â€“ Filed April 8, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Laurel R.S. Blair, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Stanley Earl McLeod, of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal by a co-trustee of an order approving a proposed division of the assets of a testamentary trust.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In 1987, W.V. Haas died testate, survived by his widow, Nell P. Haas, and four children, W.V. Haas, Jr., (Appellant) Jean H. Gillespie, John E. Haas (John), and Susan K.H. Betenbaugh (Betenbaugh).[1]Â  Haasâ€™s will established two testamentary trusts, one for Mrs. Haas and the other for Haasâ€™s children.Â  Pursuant to the terms of the will, the trusts were to be merged after the death of Haasâ€™s widow and then distributed in four equal shares:Â  one share outright to Appellant, one share outright to Gillespie, one share outright to John, and one share to be held in trust by the co-trustees for the benefit of Betenbaugh and her son.[2]Â  
In his will, Haas specified how the funds held in trust for Betenbaugh and her son were to be handled by the co-trustees.Â  The relevant provision stated as follows:Â  â€œMy Trustees . . . shall encroach upon the corpus of the trust for up to One Thousand ($1,000) Dollars per month on a non-cumulative basis for the personal living expenses of my daughter, Susan K.H. Betenbaugh.â€Â  He also named his four children as co-executors and co-trustees of his estate, with the proviso that â€œJohn Edward Haas, serve as Chairman of my Co-Executors and Co-Trustees and, in the event of any deadlock in voting . . . John Edward Haas . . . shall cast the deciding ballot and shall unilaterally determine the course of action to be taken and shall break such deadlock.â€[3]Â  
As contemplated in the will, the trusts were merged after Mrs. Haasâ€™s death in 1999; however, the co-trustees could not agree on the final distribution of trust assets or on a $12,000 distribution to Betenbaugh.Â  Because of these disagreements, Respondents filed this action in probate court requesting approval of their proposed division of the trust.Â  Appellant answered and counterclaimed, alleging Respondents breached their fiduciary duty in dividing the trust assets and in allowing the distribution to Betenbaugh.Â  Appellant also sought an accounting by Respondents and a review of compensation and fees.
The probate court found the trust was ripe for termination and distribution according to Haasâ€™s will.Â  Pursuant to South Carolina Code section 62-7-707,[4] the court found that Respondents â€œappear to constitute a majority of Trustees and may therefore divide and distribute the Trust . . . assets into four (4) equal shares, pursuant to and in compliance withâ€ Haasâ€™s will and required them to provide a written accounting to all trust beneficiaries.Â  As to the division itself, the probate court ordered that (1) for valuation purposes, the appraised value of the real property trust assets would be used without any adjustments for capital gains or real estate commissions; (2) an appraisal of trust property at Lake Hartwell would be adjusted before the final distribution to account for lots sold after the prior appraisal and for utility development costs; and (3) trust property consisting of Pawleys Island beachfront real estate could be distributed to Respondents and Gillespieâ€™s children because of their strong interest in that asset.Â  Finally, the court upheld the $12,000 distribution to Betenbaugh, finding it was neither a violation of the trust terms nor a breach of fiduciary duty.[5]Â  
Appellant then filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment of the probate court and a motion for sanctions, alleging in part:Â  (1) the probate court erred in finding Respondents did not breach their fiduciary duties or violate the terms of the trust; (2) Respondents improperly used â€œhindsightâ€ to distribute stocks based on what their market values were before the distribution; (3) Respondents did not divide the trust into four equal shares; and (4) Respondents intentionally disregarded an Architectural Review Committee concern about one of the properties distributed to Appellant.Â  The motion was held in abeyance, and the court required Respondents to complete the accounting and to address Appellantâ€™s concerns.Â  
After a hearing on the motions, the probate court issued an order denying all matters raised in Appellantâ€™s motions except for the Architectural Review Committee issue.Â  The circuit court affirmed the findings of the probate court. Â This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIf the proceeding in the probate court is in the nature of an action at law, the circuit court may not disturb the probate courtâ€™s findings of fact unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence to support them.â€[6]Â  â€œOn the other hand, if the probate proceeding is equitable in nature, the circuit court, on appeal, may make factual findings according to its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€[7]Â  When both the probate court and the circuit court, however, have considered the equitable claims and agree on the resolution of the issues, this court will not disturb their findings unless there is no evidence to support them in the record.[8]Â  
Here, then, we will reverse a factual finding by the probate court only if the record has no evidence to support it.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We find no merit to Appellantâ€™s contention that the $12,000 distribution to Betenbaugh was a cumulative distribution in violation of the trust terms. 
Although the trust specified that the distributions to Betenbaugh were to be non-cumulative, there is nothing in the trust terms that prohibited the distributions to be retained in the trust until such time as a full disbursement would be made.Â  Respondents both testified that Betenbaugh requested the $1,000 distributions but asked that they be deferred so she could save up enough money to purchase a car.Â  John testified that he made the distribution at Betenbaughâ€™s request and that Respondents, as two of the three co-trustees, approved the distribution.Â  Furthermore, Appellant himself testified that, although he did not recall Betenbaughâ€™s request, it was likely that he would have agreed to the distributions.Â  
2.Â  Appellant contends Respondents ignored assumptions and qualifications on the appraisal when making the distribution.Â  We disagree.
The trust clearly required the parties to divide the trust into four equal shares.Â  To achieve an even distribution of the trust property, the parties obtained an appraisal of all the property.Â  
Appellant points to four main reasons the use of the appraisal values was improper.Â  First, the appraisal indicated one of the properties had a blocked easement, which would prevent access to the water.Â  Second, he asserts the values used in the appraisal should have been adjusted because the property would no longer be an entire development but would be split among multiple owners.Â  Third, he maintains the property allocated to him has been affected by grading done to the remaining properties.Â  Lastly, he argues there are other water access problems with the property that would prevent the appraisals from being accurate.
We first note Appellant failed to provide any evidence of the appropriate values to assign to the properties.Â  He has not shown how any of the property values would be affected by changes to the appraisal.Â  Second, we find there is ample evidence in the record to support the probate courtâ€™s findings that the issues raised did not adversely affect the distribution or constitute breaches by Respondents of their fiduciary duty.
Although the appraisal indicated the interior lots owned by the trust may not have water access because of a fence erected by an adjoining landowner, John testified there was no fence blocking the access.Â  Appellant himself also testified the walkway is open and free from obstructions.Â  Furthermore, John testified the trust was not involved in litigation over the validity of the easement and, for the easement to be deemed abandoned, the trust would have to be a party to any litigation regarding the quality of the easement.
At trial, Appellant testified the value of the property would change if there were multiple owners trying to sell the same property.Â Â  Although the appraiser appeared to agree with this assertion, Appellant, when suggesting a division of the property, testified if one party owned the waterfront lots and another owned the interior lots, there should be no dilution of value as the parties would not be selling identical properties.Â  He testified:Â  â€œWe wouldnâ€™t be competing.Â  Iâ€™d be selling bananas and theyâ€™d be selling onions or vice versa.â€Â  The property was divided so there would be little to no competition among the owners to sell their lots.Â  In addition, neither Robinson nor Appellant attempted to quantify the diminution in the value of the property that would result from multiple ownership.
Respondents had some of the lots graded so the placement of power lines would not be disrupted when the property was developed, causing driveways and other roads to be cut into the ground.Â  Appellant presented evidence of runoff resulting from this grading but never presented any testimony regarding either the costs to fix the runoff or the diminution in the value of the property as a result of the runoff.Â  As a result, there could only be speculation as to the change in the value of the property from its appraised value.[9]
According to the appraisal, the remaining real property Appellant was to receive was a waterfront lot for which a pier permit could not be obtained because the neighboring lots had already received permits.Â  The inability to obtain a pier permit was figured into the valuation, and Appellant has not presented any evidence suggesting it was improperly disregarded in the appraisal.Â  
We therefore hold the probate court and the circuit court properly determined Respondents committed no breach of fiduciary duty in dividing the property based upon the appraised values.
3.Â  We find no merit to Appellantâ€™s contention that the division was improper because Respondents failed to give him the lots he expressed a desire to own and instead kept the property for the partnership they created to contain their shares.
The order of the probate court dated August 29, 2002, provided the distribution was to comply with S.C. Code Ann. Section 62-7-302.Â  Section 62-7-302 provides that â€œ[a] A trustee shall consider in investing and managing trust assets those circumstances of the following as are relevant to the trust or its beneficiaries: . . .(h) an assetâ€™s special relationship or special value to the purposes of the trust or to one or more of the beneficiaries.[10]
Although at trial Appellant testified he desired the waterfront lots instead of interior lots in Huntington Heights, he also acknowledged he had no â€œemotional tiesâ€ to any of the property and would be satisfied to sell all the property and receive cash. Â This admission is sufficient to support the probate courtâ€™s rejection of Appellantâ€™s assertion that Respondents failed to consider any special relationship between Appellant and the particular properties he desired to receive.
4.Â  Appellant contends Respondents distributed the stocks in the trust using market hindsight in order to distribute stocks with the greatest loss to him while retaining the other stocks for themselves.Â  In support of this argument, he notes that the stock he received in the distribution suffered a loss of 3.5 per cent whereas the stocks allocated to the other beneficiaries suffered a loss of only 1.8 per cent.Â  The probate court, however, found there was no basis for this assertion.Â  We hold the record supports this finding.
John described the method used for distributing the stocks.Â  He maintained the stocks to be distributed were selected on July 12.Â  Then using the valuations based on the July 30 statements, the final allocations of stocks were made.Â  He testified the accounts were not zeroed out until August and a dividend was received and distributed in September.Â  Specifically, John was asked â€œDid you look back at the stock values in order to determine how to attribute more losses to [Appellant]?â€Â  He responded:

We never looked back except for that reason.Â  We looked back to the July 30th time.Â  We never looked forward to see how it - - how it was affected at that time, and couldnâ€™t - - matter of fact, couldnâ€™t until we got the statement at the end of the month, unless you looked at it daily.Â  

5.Â  Finally, Appellant argues the probate court erred in finding Respondents did not breach their fiduciary duty in rejecting his offer of $730,000 for the Pawleys Island beach house, asserting he made a good faith offer that exceeded the appraised value of the property.Â  We disagree.
Appellant testified he was making the offer with the hope of altering the appraisal value for the property.Â  The record indicates he contacted the appraiser to determine whether an offer made before his appraisal would affect the value placed on the property.Â  The following colloquy explains his motives:

Q.Â Â Â Â Â  Okay.Â  And so why did you make that call to [the appraiser]?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  To find out if that would influence his appraisal.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  So that you could get a higher value for the assets to give to the other beneficiaries?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  If - - - if it was going to influence the appraisal, it would have had a bearing on what - - - at what point I made the offer, yes.Â 

In our view, this testimony is sufficient to uphold the probate courtâ€™s refusal to find that Respondents breached a fiduciary duty in refusing Appellantâ€™s offer.
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  John and Betenbaugh will also be referred to collectively as â€œRespondents.â€Â  
[2]Â  Betenbaughâ€™s son, David V. Betenbaugh, was a named party to the action.
[3] Gillespie died before this litigation ensued, and, although her children (Stephen D. Gillespie and Laura G. Greer) were made parties to this action, they were not co-trustees and were named in the will only as beneficiaries.
[4]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-7-707(a) (Supp. 2004) (providing that â€œ[a]ny power vested in three or more trustees may be exercised by a majorityâ€).
[5]Â  The probate court found that similar distributions to the other beneficiaries, including Appellant, did not violate the trust terms or constitute a breach of fiduciary duty.Â  
[6]Â  In re Howard, 315 S.C. 356, 361, 434 S.E.2d 254, 257 (1993).Â  
[7]Â  Id. at 361-62, 434 S.E.2d at 257-58. 
[8]Â  See Dean v. Kilgore, 313 S.C. 257, 260, 437 S.E.2d 154, 155-56 (Ct. App. 1993) (applying the two-judge rule to a probate court matter); cited in Geddings v. Geddings, 319 S.C. 213, 216, 460 S.E.2d 376, 378 (1995).Â  
[9]Â  Cf. Yadkin Brick Co. v. Materials Recovery Co., 339 S.C. 640, 646, 529 S.E.2d 764, 767 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œ[B]ald allegations are insufficient to establish a claim for diminution in value, and the evidence must not be speculative as to the amount of the alleged diminution.â€)
[10] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-7-302(3)(h) (Supp. 2004).

Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey A. Jacobs, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Randall Scott Tyler appeals his convictions for murder, first-degree burglary, and criminal conspiracy.Â  Tyler contends the trial court violated his constitutional right to confront an adverse witness by admitting testimonial hearsay statements made by his non-testifyingÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  co-defendant, Travis Harsey.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In July of 2002, Tyler asked his wifeâ€™s uncle, Jimmy Williams, to give him a ride to Harseyâ€™s home.Â  Williams obliged, and in the car on the way to Harseyâ€™s home, Tyler told Williams that he was mad at Robert â€œCorkyâ€ Lewis over a dispute involving money.Â  Tyler and Lewis were both drug dealers.Â  Tyler bought drugs from Lewis, and Harsey bought drugs from Tyler.Â  Tyler testified that he needed a ride to Harseyâ€™s so Harsey and he could go to Lewisâ€™s home to buy â€œcrystal methâ€ from him.
When they arrived at Harseyâ€™s home, Harsey was there along with his girlfriend and some children.Â  Tyler and Harsey went into a separate room and talked for about ten or fifteen minutes.Â  Williams entered the room to tell them he was ready to leave.Â  When he did so, he saw a magazine for a semiautomatic pistol containing what appeared to be at least one bullet lying on the bed.Â  Tyler and Harsey told Williams they were going to Lewisâ€™s home.Â  One of the children in the home observed that Harsey had a gun.Â  Everyone in the house knew about the gun before Tyler and Harsey left.Â  At that time, Tyler and Harsey were dressed in jeans or baggy pants and t-shirts.Â  
Later that night, Donna Hutto, Lewisâ€™s girlfriend, was awakened by the sound of arguing outside her home.Â  She recognized the voices of Tyler and Lewis.Â  Hutto had known Tyler for two or three years, and had seen him approximately ten to twenty times prior to the date of the incident.Â  Hutto heard Lewis identify the other speaker as â€œRandy,â€ and noticed that Lewis sounded scared.
Hutto looked out the front window to see if Tylerâ€™s car was parked outside, but saw no cars other than those belonging to Lewis and her.[1]Â  Hutto then looked into the backyard and saw Tyler walking into the garage.Â  He was wearing a baseball cap, a baseball jacket, jeans, and a partial mask.Â  Hutto recognized Tyler even though most of his face was covered.Â  She heard Tyler order Lewis to go into the house.Â  She could tell something was wrong because of the fear in Lewisâ€™s voice.Â  Hutto did not see or hear anyone else other than Lewis and Tyler. 
Concerned, Hutto left and drove to her brotherâ€™s home to call the police.Â  As she pulled out of the narrow driveway, she did not see any other vehicles.Â  When Hutto and her brother returned, Lewis was dead.
Police arrived soon afterward and found Lewis had six gunshot wounds and three blunt trauma injuries to the top of his head.Â  They found signs a struggle had occurred and that an intruder had searched the building.Â  For example, a dresser drawer in the main bedroom had been taken out and appeared to have been rummaged through.Â  Additionally, an overturned bar stool appeared to have been shoved up into the ceiling tiles in order to access an area above the ceiling where Lewis kept money.Â  Also, police found several sets of knuckle marks with traces of blood in the ceiling tiles.Â  
Hutto specifically identified Tyler as having been at her home and involved in an altercation with Lewis on the night of Lewisâ€™s murder.Â  She identified Tyler in a photo lineup without hesitation.
The next morning, Tyler told Williams that Lewis and he had argued.Â  Tyler also told Williams he had seen Harsey shoot Lewis, and he believed Lewis was dead.Â  Tyler asked Williams to fabricate an alibi that they were fishing on the date of the murder.Â  Williams initially obliged, but when pressed by police he admitted taking Tyler to Harseyâ€™s home on the day of the murder.Â  Tylerâ€™s family also told police Tyler and Williams were fishing that night.
DNA testing confirmed that the blood from the knuckle marks on the ceiling in Lewisâ€™s house was Tylerâ€™s.Â  Also, after Tyler was arrested, officers noticed healing injuries on Tylerâ€™s knuckles.
During a police interview, Harsey said that he had parked his car â€œback up towards the road hidden from [Lewisâ€™s] home.â€Â  Williamsâ€™s testimony led to Harseyâ€™s arrest and the underlying charges. 
Tyler and Harsey were tried separately.Â  At trial, Tyler testified Harsey and he were engaged in a routine drug transaction with Lewis when Harsey unexpectedly pulled a gun and attempted to rob Lewis.Â  Tyler testified he immediately ran out of the house and got into Harseyâ€™s car as Harsey was leaving.Â  Over Tylerâ€™s objections, the court admitted Harseyâ€™s hearsay statement to police that he parked his car so that it was â€œhidden from [Lewisâ€™s] homeâ€ when they visited Lewis on the night of his murder.Â  The jury convicted Tyler of all charges and sentenced him to life in prison.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  â€œWe are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.â€Â  Id. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  Concerning the admission of evidence, the trial courtâ€™s determination will be sustained absent error and resulting prejudice.Â  State v. Brown, 333 S.C. 185, 189, 508 S.E.2d 38, 40 (Ct. App. 2001).
DISCUSSION
The only issue on appeal is whether the trial court erred in admitting Harseyâ€™s hearsay statement about where he parked the car.Â  Tyler maintains admission of the statement violated his right of confrontation because Harsey was tried separately and thus could not be cross-examined at trial.Â  Although we agree that the statement should not have been admitted, we find the error harmless. 
â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  Harseyâ€™s out-of-court custodial statement was admitted at trial as a statement against interest under the hearsay exception of Rule 804(b)(3), SCRE.Â  Tyler does not dispute this ruling.Â  Instead, Tyler argues that the statement was testimonial in nature and thus violated his constitutional right of confrontation. 
The Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution provides, in relevant part, that â€œ[i]n all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right . . . to be confronted with the witnesses against him.â€Â  This provisionâ€”the â€œConfrontation Clauseâ€â€” has been incorporated through the Fourteenth Amendment and applied to both federal and state prosecutions.Â  Pointer v. Texas, 380 U.S. 400, 406 (1965).Â  The Confrontation Clause ensures the right of an accused to cross-examine witnesses against him in court.Â  Additionally, it defines the scope of the admissibility of out-of-court statements.Â  Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S. 56, 65 (1980), overruled in part by Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36 (2004).Â  
In Crawford, the United States Supreme Court held that the Confrontation Clause bars use of out-of-court statements that are testimonial in nature, unless the declarant was unavailable to testify at trial and the defendant had a prior opportunity to cross-examine that witness.Â  Crawford 541 U.S. at 53-54.Â  The Crawford court expressly declined to formulate a comprehensive definition of â€œtestimonial,â€ but noted that ex parte testimony at a preliminary hearing and statements taken by police during interrogations must be considered testimonial under any standard.Â  Id. at 51-52.Â  
Because Harsey made the statement during a custodial interview with police, the statement is testimonial under Crawford.Â  See United States v. Jones, 393 F.3d 107, 110 (2nd Cir. 2004) (noting interrogations by law enforcement officers fall squarely within the testimonial class).Â  Therefore, the admission of the statement was erroneous.Â  The State concedes this issue in its brief, as it only argues that admission of the evidence was harmless error. 
â€œIt is well established that violations of the Confrontation Clause, if preserved for appellate review, are subject to harmless error review . . . and Crawford does not suggest otherwise.â€Â  United States v. McClain, 377 F.3d 219, 222 (2nd Cir. 2004).Â  Crawford violations do not mandate a new trial where the government can show beyond a reasonable doubt the error did not contribute to the verdict obtained.Â  Id.Â  To determine whether a Crawford violation is harmless error, a court must find it clear beyond a reasonable doubt that a rational jury would have found the defendant guilty even absent the inadmissible evidence.Â  United States v. Gilbert, 391 F.3d 882, 884 (7th Cir. 2004).Â  
South Carolina law is in accordâ€”â€œ[e]rror is harmless when it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€Â  State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 144, 591 S.E.2d 646, 653 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œWhether an error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the particular case.â€Â  Id. at 144, 591 S.E.2d at 652. â€œGenerally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.â€Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 380-81, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Insubstantial errors not affecting the result are harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe admission of improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other evidence.â€Â  Pagan, 357 S.C. at 145, 591 S.E.2d at 653.
Here, we find the admission of Harseyâ€™s statement, although erroneous, was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Absent the improper hearsay, we find overwhelming evidence of Tylerâ€™s guilt as to all three charges: (1) criminal conspiracy, (2) murder, and (3) first degree burglary.Â  
Conspiracy is defined as â€œthe combination between two or more persons for the purpose of accomplishing an unlawful object or lawful object by unlawful means.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-410 (2004).Â  The gist of the offense of conspiracy is the agreement or combination.Â  State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 133, 437 S.E.2d 75, 80 (1993).Â  Under South Carolina law, no overt act in furtherance of the conspiracy is requiredâ€”the crime is the agreement itself.Â  State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 323, 555 S.E.2d 402, 405 (2001).Â  To establish the existence of a conspiracy, neither proof of an express agreement nor direct evidence are essential.Â  Id.Â  However,Â  â€œthe conspiracy may be sufficiently shown by circumstantial evidence and the conduct of the parties.â€Â  Id.Â  The State must show a shared, single criminal objective to act together for their shared mutual benefit.Â  Gunn, 313 S.C. at 134, 437 S.E.2d at 80. 
Tyler admitted Harsey and he went to Lewisâ€™s home to buy illegal drugs.Â  Additionally, circumstantial evidence suggests Tyler and Harsey were plotting to harm Lewis.Â  For example, Tyler told Williams in the car that he was mad at Lewis over a dispute involving money.Â  While at Harseyâ€™s house, Williams found the two alone in a room in which a magazine containing at least one bullet was visible.Â  One of the children in the house also saw the gun, and soon everyone in the house knew about it.Â  When Tyler and Harsey arrived at Lewisâ€™s house, Hutto noticed Tyler had changed clothes and was wearing a jacket, hat, and mask although it was mid-July.Â  Finally, evidence of Tylerâ€™s blood on the ceiling tiles suggests that Tyler did not run off immediately, as he claimed, but carried out a preconceived plan to rob Lewis.Â  
Thus, we find Tylerâ€™s guilt was conclusively proven even without the erroneously admitted evidence that Tyler and Harsey had hidden Harseyâ€™s car while at the murder scene.Â  We find admission of the statement was harmless as to the criminal conspiracy charge.Â  
We likewise find an abundance of evidence to support Tylerâ€™s burglary conviction.Â  To prove burglary in the first degree, the State must show that the defendant entered a dwelling without consent with the intent to commit a crime therein, and one of several aggravating circumstances were present.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (Supp. 2004).Â  The aggravating circumstances alleged in the indictment are established: 

(A) . . . 
  
(1) Â Â Â  when, in effecting entry or while in the dwelling or in immediate flight, he or another participant in the crime:
    
(a) Â Â Â  is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive; or
(b) Â Â Â  causes physical injury to a person who is not a participant in the crime; or
. . .
    
(2) Â Â Â  the burglary is committed by a person with a prior record of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a combination of both; or
(3) Â Â Â  the entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.
  

Id.Â  No break-in is required; it is sufficient that the entry be without consent.Â  State v. Kornahrens, 290 S.C. 281, 288 n.4, 350 S.E.2d 180, 185 n.4 (1986).
Hutto testified she saw and heard Tyler order Lewis into the house.Â  She noticed that Lewis appeared fearful.Â  Tyler does not assert that he had consent, or that the structure was not a dwelling.Â  The same evidence tending to show the existence of a conspiracy also tends to establish intent to commit a crime therein.Â  Tyler or Harsey had a gun, and Tyler donned a mask and heavy clothing to disguise his features.Â  In addition, police found the drawer had been rifled through and the ceiling damaged, and Tylerâ€™s blood was on the ceiling.Â  
Moreover, all of the aggravating factors included in the indictment are present. Either Tyler or Harsey was armed with a deadly weapon, and they inflicted physical injury toâ€”and in fact killedâ€”Lewis, who was not a party to the crime.Â  Tyler also had two prior convictions for breaking and entering with intent to steal in Michigan.Â  Finally, the intrusion occurred after dark, sometime after 10:30 p.m.Â  Thus, we find the elements of first-degree burglary are established without the improperly admitted evidence.
Finally, we find sufficient evidence to support Tylerâ€™s murder conviction.Â  Although the evidence does not clearly indicate who fired the fatal shot, the evidence nevertheless sustains Tylerâ€™s conviction.Â  Under the Pinkerton doctrine, each conspirator is liable for all acts committed in furtherance of the conspiracy regardless of which conspirator actually committed the act.Â  Pinkerton v. United States, 328 U.S. 640, 646-47 (1946); State v. Steadman, 257 S.C. 528, 543, 186 S.E.2d 712, 717 (1972); see also 16 Am. Jur. 2d Conspiracy Â§ 19 (2004).Â  Such liability is limited to acts within the scope of the conspiracy and acts reasonably foreseeably stemming from the conspiracy.Â  Pinkerton, 328 U.S. at 647-48.Â  Because evidence compellingly indicates Tyler and Harsey conspired to harm Lewis, Tyler is liable for Lewisâ€™s murder if it was committed in furtherance of the conspiracy or if it was a reasonably foreseeable result.Â  We find such evidence exists beyond a reasonable doubt.
Evidence that Tyler told Williams he was mad at Lewis and that Tyler and Harsey conversed in low tones in the back room with a gun point to the presence of malice.Â  The evidence further establishes that a physical confrontation with Lewis was within the scope of the conspiracy.Â  Moreover, evidence that Tyler wore a mask and ordered Lewis into the house, and that Tylerâ€™s blood was found on the ceiling tiles tends to show motive and a preconceived plan.Â  
Any prejudicial effect arising from the Confrontation Clause violation was minimal because Tylerâ€™s repeated attempts to mislead the police evidenced guilt and undermined his credibility.Â  Tyler admitted that he told Williams to lie to police and to tell them they were fishing.Â  Tylerâ€™s family gave police the same alibi.Â  Tyler also told police to look for his brother instead, when in fact Tylerâ€™s brother was in Michigan on the date the incident occurred.Â  
Finally, other evidence permitted an inference that the car had been hidden.Â  Hutto testified she looked out the front window and did not see a car.Â  She saw no other vehicles when she drove away.Â  An aerial photograph showed that there was no other place near the house to park.Â  We find Harseyâ€™s statement was cumulative to this evidence. 
Because we find all of Tylerâ€™s convictions are supported beyond reasonable doubt by other evidence, we find no prejudice resulted from the erroneously admitted evidence.Â  Accordingly, the Crawford violation here was harmless. 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Lewis and Hutto lived in a house set back from the road and almost completely surrounded by woods.Â  Other than the driveway and carport, the only other ordinary place to park a car was in front of the house.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDINGÂ Â  EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Marolyn L. Baril,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Aiken Regional Medical Centers,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-275
Heard March 10, 2005 â€“ Filed April 19, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard J. Morgan, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Herbert W. Louthian, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Marolyn Baril brought this action for breach of an employment contract against Aiken Regional Medical Centers (Hospital).Â  A jury returned a verdict in favor of Baril, and Hospital appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Marolyn Baril, a nurse, brought this action for breach of an alleged employment contract after she was terminated by Hospital in 1999.Â  In 2001, the circuit court, Judge Rodney A. Peeples then presiding, granted summary judgment to Hospital.Â  On appeal, we reversed and remanded the matter for trial, concluding there were genuine issues of material fact as to whether Hospitalâ€™s policies and conduct created an employment contract, whether Hospital terminated Baril with just cause, and whether Baril made reasonable efforts to mitigate her damages.Â  See Baril v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 573 S.E.2d 830 (Ct. App. 2002) (a more detailed recitation of the factual background in this case is contained in the Baril I opinion).[1]  
Upon trial, the jury returned a verdict for Baril in the amount of $210,000.00.Â  Hospital now appeals this verdict on ten enumerated grounds that can largely be grouped around its assertions that there was no evidence it breached an employment contract, Baril failed to mitigate her damages, and that the trial court failed to properly charge the jury on damages, improperly charged the jury on implied covenants and employer rights, allowed inadmissible evidence, and failed to grant Hospitalâ€™s post-trial motions.Â  A review of these issues follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Breach of an Employment Contract 
Hospital argues that, even assuming the parties entered into a contractual relationship, it did not breach the alleged agreement.Â  Hospital asserts an employer is not liable for breach of contract if the employer had a reasonable, good faith belief (even if mistaken) that it had just cause to terminate an employee, and the undisputed evidence in this case is that it was justified in its belief it had cause for termination.Â  We disagree.
While Hospital does not characterize its argument as the trial court erred in failing to grant either a directed verdict or a judgment notwithstanding the verdict, this is inherent in its position.Â  
â€œWhen reviewing the denial of a motion for directed verdict or judgment notwithstanding the verdict, this Court must employ the same standard as the trial courtâ€”that is, we must consider the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Sauers v. Poulin Bros. Homes, Inc., 328 S.C. 601, 605, 493 S.E.2d 503, 504-05 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  
â€œIn ruling on motions for directed verdict and JNOV [judgment notwithstanding the verdict], the trial court is required . . . to deny the motions where either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.â€Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003) (quoting Strange v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 429-30, 445 S.E.2d 439, 440 (1994)).Â  
â€œThis Court will reverse the trial courtâ€™s rulings on these motions only where there is no evidence to support the rulings or where the rulings are controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Hinkle v. Natâ€™l Cas. Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 92, 96, 579 S.E.2d 616, 618 (2003).Â  â€œWhen considering the motions, neither this Court nor the trial court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony and evidence.â€Â  Sauers, 328 S.C. at 605, 493 S.E.2d at 505. 
Hospitalâ€™s argument is, in essence, that it did not knowingly allow other employees to place long-distance telephone calls through its toll-free line or allow any employee to instruct coworkers to violate a Hospital policy.Â  Hospital further asserts it â€œhad no legal or contractual duty to conduct a more laborious, time-consuming investigation than it conducted to support its decision.â€Â  It also points to the fact that ten other employees had been fired over a three-year period for various instances of fraud, theft, or dishonesty.Â  
In reviewing the record, however, we conclude there was testimony suggesting that Hospital did not have a reasonable, good faith belief for its termination of Baril.Â  First, Hospital knew of prior tension between Baril and one of her coworkers, Holly Martinez de Andino.Â  Second, it made the decision to fire Baril before hearing her explanation of the incident.Â  Third, Barilâ€™s proffered explanation was reasonable on its face.Â  Fourth, Hospital never interviewed Beth Pearson, the nurse Baril had initially spoken to before another employee transferred the call, to seek her description of the event.Â  Fifth, there was testimony that other people had similarly used Hospitalâ€™s toll-free number.Â  In this case, Barilâ€™s call had a nexus to Hospitalâ€™s work, as she would not have called had she not received the message that Hospital was looking for her.Â  Considering this and all of the evidence in the light most favorable to Baril, as we are required to do, we conclude the trial court did not err in submitting the case to the jury and in denying the motions for a directed verdict and a judgment notwithstanding the verdict.
II.Â  Damages 
Hospital next argues that Baril should be barred from any recovery in this action because she failed to mitigate her damages and that the trial court committed error in its instructions on the issues of future and nominal damages.Â  We disagree.
a.Â  Mitigation 
In Baril I we stated the rule on mitigation and noted that, generally, it is for a jury to determine whether a party acted reasonably to mitigate damages:

A party injured by the acts of another is required to do those things a person of ordinary prudence would do under the circumstances, but the law does not require him to exert himself unreasonably or incur substantial expense to avoid damages.Â  Whether the party acted reasonably to mitigate damages is ordinarily a question for the jury.

Baril I, 352 S.C. at 285, 573 S.E.2d at 838 (citation omitted).
At trial, Baril offered several reasons for her failure to seek employment at another hospital immediately after her termination.Â  First, she explained that she did not want to reveal to potential employers in the medical field that she had been fired, which would impugn her reputation.[2]Â  Second, she testified that she went to school for an extended period to become a family nurse practitioner.Â  Third, she would have had to leave her residence in Aiken to find another hospital position.Â  Fourth, Baril continued in a teaching position at the University of South Carolina at Aiken that she had held before her termination by Hospital and any further employment would have interfered with her teaching schedule.Â  At the time of this trial in 2003, Baril had resigned her teaching position and accepted full-time employment as a nurse practitioner, but she was laid off from that position prior to trial and was again seeking employment.Â Â Â  
In Baril I we found material issues of fact existed as to whether Baril made reasonable efforts to mitigate her damages; we concluded reasonable minds could disagree, so the issue should be resolved by a jury and not as a matter of law by the court.Â  Baril I, 352 S.C. at 285, 573 S.E.2d at 838.Â  
We again conclude the evidence presented issues of fact for determination by a jury as to whether Baril adequately mitigated her damages.Â  Moreover, we note the trial court correctly charged the jury that a discharged individual â€œis obligated to mitigate damages by accepting available alternative employment of the same or similar character.â€Â  The court further stated:Â  â€œ[A] party who claims that damages should have been minimized has the burden of proving that they could have been avoided or reduced, and itâ€™s up to you, the jury, to determine whether or not the employee has fully mitigated her damages.â€Â  Thus, the jury was free to accept or reject the testimony it heard regarding mitigation and to consider Barilâ€™s actions in determining her damages.Â  
b.Â  Future Damages 
Hospital next contends the trial court erred in charging the jury on future damages because no evidence warranted such a charge.Â  Hospital does not argue the charge as given was not a correct statement of the law; rather, it reasserts its mitigation argument, asserting Baril was not entitled to future damages because she did not seek employment for two years.Â Â Â  
Our supreme court has made it clear that future damages are recoverable in actions for wrongful termination:Â  â€œA wrongfully discharged employee suing for breach of contract is entitled to receive the amount of the employeesâ€™ net losses caused by the employerâ€™s breach.Â  Such losses may include back pay as well as future damages.â€Â 
Small v. Springs Indus., Inc., 300 S.C. 481, 484, 388 S.E.2d 808, 810 (1990) (citations omitted).Â  
â€œUnder current South Carolina law, the standard of admissibility for evidence of future damages is â€˜any evidence which tends to establish the nature, character, and extent of injuries which are the natural and proximate consequences of the defendantâ€™s acts . . . if otherwise competent.â€™â€Â 
Pearson v. Bridges, 344 S.C. 366, 372, 544 S.E.2d 617, 620 (2001) (quoting Martin v. Mobley, 253 S.C. 103, 109, 169 S.E.2d 278, 281-82 (1969)).Â  
In the case before us, the trial court charged the jury according to current law.Â  We can find no error warranting reversal in this regard, especially in light of the fact that we have determined the court did not err in its rulings on the issue of mitigation.
c.Â  Nominal Damages 
Hospital also contends the trial court erred in refusing its request to charge the jury on nominal damages. 
â€œThe law to be charged to the jury is determined by the evidence at trial.â€Â  Frazier v. Badger, 361 S.C. 94, 101, 603 S.E.2d 587, 590 (2004).Â  â€œIn reviewing jury charges for error, appellate courts must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.â€Â  Id.
Because we reject Hospitalâ€™s argument that Baril failed, as a matter of law, to mitigate damages and find Baril did introduce evidence of a loss of income, we conclude a charge on nominal damages is not supported by the facts of the case.Â  See Cleveland v. Bryant, 16 S.C. 634, 635 (1882) (â€œIt is only in cases destitute of facts that the judge is warranted in charging [on nominal damages] as requested here.Â  A judge may err in acceding to requests of the kind made in this case, but he will seldom err in refusing them; certainly, in such refusals as to matters of fact he should be safe from reversal by this court.â€).
III.Â  Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair DealingÂ  
Hospital next argues the trial court erred in allowing Baril to seek recovery for breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing because she never pled this cause of action.Â  We disagree.
Our recent decision in RoTec Services, Inc. v. Encompass Services, Inc., 359 S.C. 467, 472-73, 597 S.E.2d 881, 884 (Ct. App. 2004) makes it clear that the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing is not an independent cause of action, but is an implied term in every contract that is subsumed in a claim for breach of contract.Â  Thus, Baril was not required to plead breach of the implied covenant as a separate claim.
IV.Â  Employersâ€™ RightsÂ  
Hospital contends the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on employersâ€™ rights.Â  We disagree.
Hospital specifically asserts:Â  â€œThe Trial Courtâ€™s refusal to charge the jury on the rights of employers prejudiced [it], as it had the unfettered right to determine the level and severity of its employeesâ€™ misconduct.Â  The Trial Court erroneously deprived the jury of this legal standard . . . .â€Â  
One example of Hospitalâ€™s proposed jury charges on employersâ€™ rights is as follows:

Employers enjoy the latitude and autonomy to make whatever business decisions they desire and to establish and enforce whatever policies and procedures that they deem appropriate.
Employers, and not employees, have the right to determine the level of severity of an employeeâ€™s misconduct and to apply [its] policies accordingly.Â  

Along these lines, Hospital also proposed charges related to Barilâ€™s duty of loyalty, such as employees â€œmust, at all times, abide by and follow their employerâ€™s instructions and policies . . . even if the employee considers those instructions and policies harsh and severe.â€Â  Another one instructed that if an employee is disloyal, he or she can forfeit the right to notice or a lesser disciplinary action and could be barred from receiving damages.Â Â Â  
â€œIn reviewing jury charges for error, appellate courts must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.â€Â  Frazier v. Badger, 361 S.C. 94, 101, 603 S.E.2d 587, 590 (2004).Â  â€œIf the instructions of the trial court, construed as a whole, correctly state the law, there is no reversible error.â€Â  Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 53, 557 S.E.2d 676, 686 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œTo entitle an appellant to reversal, the trial courtâ€™s instructions must be not only erroneous, but also prejudicial, and the enumeration of hypercritical exceptions will not suffice to overthrow a juryâ€™s verdict.â€Â  Id.
We have reviewed Hospitalâ€™s proposed charges and find no error in the trial courtâ€™s instructions to the jury.Â  We conclude the trial courtâ€™s instructions fairly set forth the law and we discern no prejudice to Hospital.Â  In the first instance, the charges regarding an employerâ€™s unfettered right to set policy is a broad generalization that is not applicable here.Â  We further conclude the charges related to Barilâ€™s duty of loyalty are factually inappropriate to this case.
V.Â  Evidence 
Hospital alleges the trial court erred in allowing certain testimony about its disciplinary policy and employeesâ€™ use of Hospitalâ€™s toll-free number.Â  We disagree.
a.Â  Statements Regarding the Disciplinary PolicyÂ  
Hospital argues the trial court erred in allowing testimony that Richard Lowe, Hospitalâ€™s Director of Human Resources, told Baril that Hospital policies, particularly the progressive disciplinary policy, would prevent her from being targeted for termination.Â  
Hospital argues this evidence should have been excluded because Baril never alleged an oral contract and this evidence violated the parol evidence rule by allowing extrinsic evidence regarding a promise of fairness.Â  Contrary to Hospitalâ€™s assertion, we do not regard this evidence as an attempt to demonstrate an oral contract.Â  Rather, it was meant to reveal Hospitalâ€™s own understanding and intent with regard to its employment handbook.Â  Thus, we find no error in this regard.
b.Â  Use of Toll-Free Number 
Hospital also argues the trial court should not have allowed testimony of other employeesâ€™ use of Hospitalâ€™s toll-free number because Baril did not demonstrate Hospital management ever allowed employees to use the toll-free number in such a manner.Â  
Baril presented evidence that although she was terminated for using the toll-free line for personal use, she had actually used it for the business purpose of responding to a call placed by Hospital.Â  Baril had also contended Hospital did not have a published policy on the use of the toll-free number and that no one had ever been fired based on alleged misuse of the number.Â  Baril presented the evidence of other employeesâ€™ use of the toll-free number to demonstrate other employees did not regard this as a Hospital policy.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s admission of this testimony.Â  See Gamble v. Intâ€™l Paper Realty Corp., 323 S.C. 367, 474 S.E.2d 438 (1996) (stating the admission or exclusion of evidence rests in the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion).
VI.Â  Post-Trial Motions 
Finally, Hospital asserts the trial court should have granted its motion for a remittitur or exercised its power under the thirteenth juror doctrine to grant a new trial.Â  We disagree.
In its motion to alter or amend the judgment, Hospital maintained the evidence indicated Baril suffered either no damages or only nominal damages and â€œ[c]ertainly, there should be no future damages.â€Â  Alternatively, Hospital argues its motion for a new trial nisi remittitur should have been granted and Barilâ€™s damages should be reduced for the two years she did not specifically pursue employment in another hospital setting.Â  As to its request for a new trial absolute under the thirteenth juror doctrine, Hospital contended the juryâ€™s questions regarding whether it was to determine if Baril were treated fairly indicate the jury did not understand the trial courtâ€™s instructions; therefore, the trial court should have granted a new trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  
â€œOn appeal, this court presumes the jury awarded an amount of damages within its discretion and it views all the evidence and the inferences reasonably deducible therefrom in the light most favorable to sustaining the verdict.â€Â  Howle v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 288 S.C. 586, 601, 344 S.E.2d 157, 165 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  â€œThe denial of a motion for a new trial nisi is within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 527, 431 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1993).Â  â€œ[O]n appeal of the denial of a motion for a new trial nisi, this Court will reverse when the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive requiring the granting of a new trial absolute.â€Â 
Id.
â€œUnlike a motion for directed verdict, the trial judge weighs the evidence under the thirteenth juror doctrine and need not view it in the light most favorable to the opposing party.â€Â  McEntire v. Mooregard Exterminating Servs., Inc., 353 S.C. 629, 633, 578 S.E.2d 746, 748 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œMoreover, the question of whether to grant a new trial upon the facts is one addressed to the discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œIn reviewing the denial of a motion for a new trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine, we consider only whether there is any evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  Haselden v. Davis, 341 S.C. 486, 506, 534 S.E.2d 295, 306 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d, 353 S.C. 481, 579 S.E.2d 293 (2003).Â  â€œTo reverse such a denial, we must find the moving party was entitled to a directed verdict at trial.â€Â  Id.Â  
Hospitalâ€™s remittitur argument essentially reiterates its previous arguments regarding mitigation.Â  We have previously determined that mitigation was properly submitted to the jury.Â  We, therefore, find no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  We likewise find there is evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny a new trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine as there was sufficient evidence to present a jury question in this case.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the judgment below is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Hospital terminated Baril in 1999 after she reportedly used Hospitalâ€™s toll-free line to make a personal call while she was on vacation in Washington state.Â  Hospital found the call violated its written policy HR116 prohibiting â€œ[d]ishonesty, fraud, theft (regardless of amount), [or] unauthorized removal of hospital property,â€ each of which constituted a â€œcritical offenseâ€ warranting immediate termination.Â Â Â Â  
Barilâ€™s explanation was that she called Hospital on the toll-free line after receiving a message from her sister that Hospital was looking for her.Â  When Baril finished speaking to Hospitalâ€™s staff, she asked to be transferred to her sister to follow up. According to Hospitalâ€™s phone bill, Baril spoke to her sister for about .32 of a minute, or about twenty seconds.Â  Baril told her sister that she had received the message and that she had confirmed that Hospital knew she was on vacation, so nothing further was needed.Â Â Â  
Baril offered to pay for the call, but Hospital refused to accept payment.Â  There is no evidence in the record as to any monetary loss suffered by Hospital for the call.Â  Baril believed the true cause of her termination was not the call, but that another employee, Holly Martinez de Andino, had targeted her for termination.Â  
[2]Â  Baril did, however, work at several part-time positions as a nurse practitioner that did not require her to reveal her separation from Hospital.Â  For example, she worked at a clinic and also with a physician who already knew her.Â
