THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Annette M. Collins,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Paul D. Collins,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Dale Moore Gable, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-276
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 19, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART
REVERSED IN PART
AND MODIFIED


  
    
      
John L. Creson, of Augusta, for Appellant.
Jeffrey Raymond Moorehead, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â In this domestic action, Paul D. Collins (Husband) argues on appeal that the family court judge erred in providing an outline of her decision to the parties to use in drafting the proposed order.Â  Additionally, Husband contests alimony, fairness of the division of property, transmutation of a car he owned prior to the marriage, and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, modify in part, and reverse in part.
FACTS
Husband and Annette M. Collins (Wife) were married in 1983.Â  The parties had two sons, one born in 1984 and one born in 1988.Â  The parties separated in February 2002 when Wife and the children left the marital home.Â  On March 15, 2002, Wife brought a pro se action for child support.Â  After Husband filed an answer and a counterclaim for separate support and maintenance, Wife retained counsel and filed an amended complaint in which she also sought separate support and maintenance.Â  
The family court judge issued a temporary order granting sole custody of the children to wife.Â  Husband was ordered to pay $479.30 per month in child support for the two children, decreasing to $322.48 after the oldest son reached the age of majority in August 2002.Â  Husband was further ordered to pay $800 per month in alimony.Â  
After the hearing, the family court judge provided counsel for each of the parties with an outline of her decision and instructed Wifeâ€™s counsel to prepare a draft order.Â  The order awarded sole custody of the children to Wife and specified the visitation schedule for Husband.Â  Husband was ordered to pay child support of $106.13 per week and alimony of $560 per month.Â  The marital home and the land were awarded to Husband, but he was ordered to pay Wife 50% of the property value within 60 days after the order was filed.Â  Wife was allowed to keep the marital lot, on which she placed the mobile home in which she was living, with a 50% offset to Husband.Â  The marital personal property was divided approximately 50/50.Â  A Camaro Z28 automobile owned by Husband prior to the marriage was included as marital property and awarded to Husband.Â  Finally, Husband was ordered to pay Wifeâ€™s attorney fees in the amount of $1,500.Â Â  
Both parties filed motions to alter and amend the judgment.Â  The family court judge denied both motions.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Use of Outline
Husband first argues that the family court judge erred in providing an outline of her decision to both parties to aid in drafting the final order.Â  Husband argues the outline rendered it unclear whether the family court judge considered all the factors required by law in reaching her decision, and it provided insufficient guidance for preparation of the final order.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code lists fifteen factors for the court to consider in equitably apportioning a marital estate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2004); Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Similarly, section 20-3-130(C) requires the family court judge to consider thirteen factors in determining alimony.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2004); Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 290, 555 S.E.2d 386, 390 (2001).Â  This court will affirm an order for equitable distribution if it can be determined that the family court judge addressed the statutory factors sufficiently for us to conclude she was cognizant of the factors.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Neither the apportionment of marital property nor the decision to award alimony will be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Hinson .v Hinson, 341 S.C. 574, 577, 535 S.E.2d 143, 144 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting the decision to award alimony will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion); Bungener v. Bungener, 291 S.C. 247, 251, 353 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 1987) (holding the apportionment of marital property is discretionary).Â  
The family court judgeâ€™s outline as provided to the parties merely indicated her ultimate decision regarding distribution and alimony; it did not recite that the judge had considered all the factors required by law in reaching her decision.Â  Nevertheless, in the final order, each statutory factor was considered and discussed.Â  The order noted the length of the marriage, the party having primary custody of the minor children, the partiesâ€™ respective earnings, and the identity and value of the marital property.Â  Further, the section addressing alimony specifically listed eighteen reasons supporting an award of alimony, including the age and health of the parties, the contributions made to the marriage by each party, the conduct of each party, and the standard of living of the parties.Â  The family court judge signed the order and denied Husbandâ€™s motion to alter or amend the order based upon the use of the outline.Â  We find sufficient evidence that the family court judge considered all the factors required by law.Â  The family court judge also had the opportunity to make any changes she thought necessary before she signed the order.Â  Thus, there was no abuse of discretion.
II. Alimony
Relying upon E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992), and on Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 489 S.E.2d 212 (Ct. App. 1997), Husband argues the family court judge erred in awarding alimony to Wife because she is self-supporting and he has no financial ability to pay her alimony.Â  He further asserts that the amount of alimony was excessive.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 183-84, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support that is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 599, 506 S.E.2d 1, 9 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse in the position he or she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Id.Â  However, alimony should not â€œserve as a disincentive for spouses to improve their employment potential or to dissuade them from providing, to the extent possible, for their own support.â€Â  Id.Â  
This case was an action for separate maintenance, not a divorce.Â  In actions for separate maintenance, alimony is to be awarded according to the factors applied in divorce actions.Â  Riverbark v. Riverbark, 301 S.C. 175, 178, 391 S.E.2d 232, 233 (1990); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-140 (Supp. 2004)(noting that when determining alimony in actions for separate support and maintenance, the family court considers the factors for awarding alimony in a divorce action).Â  Factors to be considered in making an alimony award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and non-marital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations; and (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2004).Â  Permanent periodic alimony is the favored form of alimony under South Carolina law.Â  Jenkins, 345 S.C. at 95, 545 S.E.2d at 535.Â  â€œIf a claim for alimony is well-founded, the law favors the award of permanent periodic alimony.â€Â  Id.Â  
As noted above, the family court judge considered all the statutory factors in reaching her decision, especially the income, financial condition, and standard of living of the parties.Â  The judge noted that Wife had living expenses of $1,269.50 per month and an imputed minimum wage income of $892.67 per month.Â  Wife was also awarded $101.08 per week in child support.[1]Â  Although the judge found Wife would benefit from further education, the judge also found that further education would not substantially increase Wifeâ€™s income potential.Â  The judge noted that Wifeâ€™s standard of living substantially decreased upon the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  
As to Husband, the family court judge noted that he earned $3,871.11 in gross monthly income, had $2,192 in monthly expenses, and would receive $37,500 in marital property in the equitable distribution.Â  Considering those factors and the great likelihood that Husbandâ€™s income would increase, the judge specifically found that Husband would be able to pay alimony in the amount of $560 per month.Â  In awarding Wife $560 in permanent, periodic alimony, the family court judge reduced Husbandâ€™s prior $800 alimony obligation from the temporary order.Â  
We find no abuse of discretion in the award of alimony to Wife.Â  Wife earned substantially less than Husband and suffered a decrease in her standard of living.Â  Based upon Husbandâ€™s gross income at the time of the final hearing, Husband should be able to pay his own expenses, child support, and $560 in alimony to Wife each month, with funds remaining.Â  Thus, despite Wifeâ€™s ability to earn her own income, we find the award and amount of alimony was supported by the record.[2]Â  
III. Equitable Distribution
Husband argues the family court judge erred in equitably dividing the marital property.Â  Specifically, Husband faults the judgeâ€™s inclusion of a Camaro owned prior to the marriage as marital property to be divided and the decision to award 50% of the interest in the marital home to Wife.Â  We agree in part.
A. Transmutation of the Camaro Z28 Automobile
â€œThe apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Greene, 351 S.C. at 340, 569 S.E.2d at 399.Â  If the family court judge weighs the factors listed in the statute, the decision will be affirmed on appeal regardless of whether this court might have weighed the specific factors differently.Â  Id.Â  Our focus is on the overall fairness of the apportionment.Â  Id.  
Under the equitable apportionment statute, only marital assets are divided.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2004).Â  Marital property is defined in section 20-7-473 as â€œall real and personal property acquired by the parties during the marriage which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation, regardless of how legal title is held.â€Â  Hatfield, 327 S.C. at 368, 489 S.E.2d at 217.Â  
Property owned by one of the spouses before the marriage, however, can be transmuted into marital property.Â  Transmutation occurs when nonmarital property:Â  â€œ(1) becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable; (2) is titled jointly; or (3) is utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property.â€Â  Id.Â  The spouse claiming transmutation bears the burden of producing objective evidence that the parties regarded the property as common property during the marriage.Â  Greene, 351 S.C. at 338, 569 S.E.2d at 398.Â  â€œThe mere use of separate property to support the marriage, without some additional evidence of intent to treat the property as marital, is not sufficient to establish transmutation.â€Â  Id.
Both parties testified that Husband owned the Camaro prior to the marriage.Â  However, there was conflicting testimony as to whether the car was debt-free at the time of the marriage.Â  Wife testified that Husband had taken out a second loan on the car that he continued to pay after the parties married.Â  Husband testified that the loan was paid off before the marriage began.Â  Husband also admitted that Wife drove the car â€œfor awhile during the marriage.â€Â  The family court judge found the Camaro was marital property, valued the car at $1,000, and awarded it to Husband in the 50/50 division of the property.Â Â  
The only evidence presented at trial was that Husband owned the car prior to the marriage and that Wife used the car on occasion.Â  We can discern no evidence from the record that the parties intended the Camaro to be marital property.Â  Wifeâ€™s mere use of Husbandâ€™s car on occasion would not support transmutation, absent more.Â  Further, the fact that Husband continued to pay on the car after the parties married would not indicate an intent to transmute the car.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the family court judgeâ€™s finding that the car was marital.
In the instant case, the family court judge ordered a division of the property resulting in a near 50/50 split.Â  There is nothing in the record meriting a reversal of this provision.Â  As discussed above, the family court judge considered all the statutory factors in making her decision.Â  Therefore, we affirm the order to the extent that it calls for a 50/50 split of the marital property.Â  However, because we find the family court judge erred in awarding the Camaro to Husband as part of his 50% share of the marital estate, we modify the order by reducing the total marital estate by $1,000, the value of the Camaro.Â  Husband shall be awarded $500 to bring his property award closer to the 50/50 division the family court judge intended.Â Â  
B. Disposition of the Marital Home
Husband asserts the judge erred in awarding Wife a one-half interest in the marital home by failing to consider the amount of alimony Husband was required to pay, his inability to pay his own expenses, and his inability to pay Wife her half-interest in the home without selling the home. Â 
â€œIn order to effect an equitable apportionment, the family court may require the sale of marital property and a division of the proceeds.â€Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 360, 384 S.E.2d 741, 745 (1989).Â  The family court can also grant one spouse title to the marital home as part of the equitable distribution.Â  Id.Â  
The family court judge awarded the marital home to Husband.Â  However, to effectuate a 50/50 division of the marital property, Husband was required to pay Wife her half-interest in the home within sixty days after the order was filed.Â  Since the house was valued at $26, 941, this payment, minus offsets, totaled $12, 471.Â  
We see no impropriety in the amount of the award.Â  As previously discussed, the family court judge considered the statutory factors in rendering a division of the marital estate.Â  However, we find the judgeâ€™s requirement that Husband pay Wife her 50% interest in the house within sixty days to be inequitable insofar as it would require Husband to dip into his retirement.Â  Accordingly, we modify the family court judgeâ€™s award to allow Husband ninety days to either sell or mortgage the house in order to raise the funds necessary to pay Wife if he is unable to pay her half-interest. 
IV. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband argues the family court judge erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife because she is self-supporting and the award of alimony was improper.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
The family court may order payment of attorneyâ€™s fees to a party pursuant to statute.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(H) (Supp. 2004).Â  Whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial court, and the award will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bowen v. Bowen, 372 S.C. 561, 563, 490 S.E.2d 271, 272 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The family court should consider: the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fee; the beneficial results obtained by counsel; the financial conditions of the parties; and the effect of the fee on each partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  E.D.M., 307 S.C. at 476-77, 415 S.E.2d at 816.Â  To determine the amount of an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider: the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; the time necessarily devoted to the case; counselâ€™s professional standing; the contingency of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991). 
Husband essentially argues that the award of $1,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife should be reversed because it was based primarily upon the award of alimony.Â  As previously discussed, we believe the alimony award was proper.Â  Further, we find no abuse of discretion in the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court judge specifically noted in the final order that beneficial results were obtained for Wife in that she prevailed on the issue of alimony.Â  The judge considered the nature of the action, the complexity of the issues presented, the time devoted to the case, the skill and reputation of Wifeâ€™s attorney, and the partiesâ€™ respective abilities to pay.Â  Accordingly, we find no error with the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
We hold that the family court judge did not abuse her discretion in providing an outline to the parties to aid in drafting an order.Â  We further find no abuse of discretion in the award of alimony and the amount awarded.Â  We affirm the equitable distribution scheme to the extent that it provides for a 50/50 division of the property.Â  We reverse the final order as to the transmutation of the automobile and modify the 50/50 division of marital property to award Husband $500 to bring his property award closer to the 50/50 division intended.Â  We modify the order so as to allow Husband 90 days to sell or mortgage the marital home if he is unable to pay Wife her share.Â  Finally, we affirm the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family courtâ€™s order is therefore
 AFFIRMED in part, MODIFIED in part, and REVERSED in part. 
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Â As of February 10, 2005, the partiesâ€™ youngest child should have reached the age of seventeen.Â  However, the family court judgeâ€™s order failed to indicate whether Husbandâ€™s child support obligation would end when the child reached the age of eighteen.Â  Accordingly, we do not know when Husbandâ€™s child support obligation ends.Â  Because neither party raised this issue on appeal, it is not before us on review.Â  
[2] Further, we find Husbandâ€™s reliance upon E.D.M. and Hatfield misplaced as the facts are distinguishable.Â  In E.D.M., our supreme court found alimony to the wife was inappropriate as she was employed, self-sufficient, had significant savings, had medical expenses that were likely to decrease in the future, and made minimal contributions during the four-and-a-half year marriage.Â  E.D.M., 307 S.C. at 476, 415 S.E.2d at 815-16.Â  Likewise, in Hatfield, this court affirmed the family court judgeâ€™s denial of alimony to the wife where she had ample means to support herself.Â  Hatfield, 327 S.C. at 367, 489 S.E.2d at 216 (noting that the wife had a bachelorâ€™s degree in business administration and two associateâ€™s degrees, had been in the workplace for many years, held many responsible positions, had substantial assets, and was considerably younger than the husband).Â  Here, the family court judge found that although Wife could work, her standard of living since the time of separation had decreased and she was in need of alimony.Â  We agree with this finding.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,

Jermaine Jackson,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-277
Submitted April 1, 2005- Filed April 20, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â

PER CURIAM:Â  Jermaine Jackson appeals his guilty plea to assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Counsel for Jackson attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Jackson did not file a separate pro se response.
After a review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable issues that are arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss Jacksonâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Case No.: 2002-CP-46-127
Bank of America, N.A., f/k/a NationsBank, N.A.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Brian K. Wells, The Allen Tate Company, Inc., Leeds Building Products, Inc., Charlotte Hardwood Center, Inc., and States Resources Corp.,       
Defendants,
Of Whom Brian K. Wells is the       
Appellant.Appellant.
        
Case No.: 2002-CP-46-1803
Brian K. Wells and J. Scott Wells,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bank of America, N.A., Allen Tate Company, Inc., Leeds Building Products, Inc., The Hardwood Group, Inc., f/k/a Charlotte Hardwood Center, Inc., States Resources Corp., Walter G. Matthews, Carol A. Matthews, and John Doe,       
Defendants,
Of Whom Bank of America, N.A, States Resources Corp., and Walter G. Matthews and Carol A. Matthews are the       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-279
Heard January 13, 2005 â€“ Filed April 20, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John Martin Foster, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
Cari V. Hicks, Earle G. Prevost, of Greenville, Charles S. Bradford, of York and Michael E.
Kozlarek, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This case relates to the foreclosure sale of certain real property.Â  Owner Brian K. Wells and his brother J. Scott Wells appeal from an order of the master-in-equity denying Brianâ€™s motion for relief from the judgment and dismissing Brian and Scottâ€™s independent action in equity.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Brian owned a parcel of real property in York County worth approximately $135,000.[1]Â  On March 12, 1998,[2] Brian executed a note and mortgage in the amount of $46,662 against the property in favor of NationsBank, which is now Bank of America.Â Â  
Brian defaulted on the mortgage and Bank of America brought a foreclosure action in 2002.Â  Brian failed to answer or otherwise plead.Â  Bank of America sent Brian notice of the foreclosure hearing, but he failed to appear.Â  Brian has admitted that he knew of both the foreclosure and the hearing.Â  The master entered a decree of foreclosure on May 16, 2002, and the decree was served upon Brian.Â  Brian did not appeal from this decree. 
The decree directed that the property be sold at a public sale on July 1, 2002.Â  Because Bank of America also sought a deficiency judgment, the decree provided, in relevant part, as follows:

Because a personal deficiency judgment has been sought, the sale will not be final as of the closing of bidding on sales day but will remain open for thirty (30) days for upset bids.Â  Plaintiff reserves the right to waive its right to a deficiency, which deficiency waiver may be in writing prior to the sale.Â  

The Notice of Sale was advertised in The Herald for three consecutive weeks and provided, in relevant part, as follows:

Since a deficiency judgment is being sought, bidding will not be final as of sales day but will remain open for 30 days for upset bids.Â  The plaintiff reserves the right to waive deficiency up to and including the date of the sale.Â  

On June 28, 2002, the Friday before the Monday on which the public sale was scheduled, Bank of America waived its right to a deficiency judgment by a letter to the master.Â  Brian was not sent a copy of this letter.Â Â Â  
Brian did not attend the July 1, 2002 public sale.Â  At the sale, the master announced that the deficiency had been waived, so the sale would be final at the close of the bidding.Â  Walter G. Matthews and Carol A. Matthews were the successful bidders and bought the property for $52,100.48.Â  The Matthews were given a Masterâ€™s Deed for the property and asserted control over the property by evicting Brian.Â  
Brian subsequently filed a motion under Rule 60(b), SCRCP, for relief from the judgment.Â  Brian and Scott also filed a separate action in equity to collaterally attack the judgment and sale.Â  Scott alleged that he was a creditor of Brian and that Brianâ€™s lost ability to bid on the property deprived Brian of the funds to repay him.Â  After a hearing, the master issued an order reaffirming the sale and ratifying the deed to the Matthews.Â Â  
Brian and Scott filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment which was denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Motions for relief under Rule 60(b) are within the masterâ€™s discretion, and will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Hillman v. Pinion, 347 S.C. 253, 255-56, 554 S.E.2d 427, 429 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the masterâ€™s order is controlled by an error of law or is without evidentiary support.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Rule 60(b) Motion
Brian[3] argues that the master should have granted his motion for relief from judgment because the judgment was the result of excusable neglect and the judgment was void.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œIn determining whether to grant a motion under Rule 60(b), the trial judge should consider: (1) the promptness with which relief is sought, (2) the reasons for the failure to act promptly, (3) the existence of a meritorious defense, and (4) the prejudice to the other party.â€Â  Mictronics, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 510-11, 548 S.E.2d 223, 226 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Brian seeks relief based upon two grounds: (1) excusable neglect or mistake; and (2) that the judgment is void. 
A. Excusable Neglect
Brian initially argues that he did not know that Bank of America had waived its right to seek a deficiency judgment because he was never served with the notice.Â  Thus, he argues, he was prejudiced because he had no notice the sale would be final, denying both Brian and Scott the opportunity to place upset bids thirty days after the sale.Â  
Pursuant to Rule 60(b)(1), SCRCP, a court â€œmay relieve a party . . . from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for . . . mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect.â€Â  Rule 60(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  However, a party may not invoke Rule 60(b) as a substitute for an appeal from a final judgment, particularly when the issue could have been litigated at trial and on appeal.Â  Tench v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Educ., 347 S.C. 117, 121, 553 S.E.2d 451, 453 (2001).Â  Instead, Rule 60(b) â€œis an appropriate remedy for good faith mistakes of fact if all other applicable factors are met.â€Â  Hillman, 347 S.C. at 256, 554 S.E.2d at 429.Â  This rule generally may not be used as a vehicle for relief from mistakes of law.Â  Id.Â  Failure to understand the legal process does not constitute excusable neglect under Rule 60(b).Â  Hill v. Dotts, 345 S.C. 304, 310, 547 S.E.2d 894, 897 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Brian knew that his property was to be sold on July 1, 2002, and he failed to take any action in that regard.Â  He essentially argues that he would have taken some action to protect himself if he had known what the post-foreclosure sale procedures would have been.Â  As will be discussed in more detail below, Rule 71(b), SCRCP, allows a creditor to waive the right to a deficiency judgment in writing at any time prior to the sale.Â  Thus, Bank of America acted within its authority to waive a deficiency judgment.Â  Brianâ€™s decision not to protect his rights through appearance and his misunderstanding regarding what would happen after the foreclosure sale did not rise to the level of mistake or excusable neglect.Â  His actions, instead, amounted to a mistake of law and relief was not available under Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the masterâ€™s decision to deny relief pursuant to Rule 60(b) in this regard.
B. Void Judgment
Brian next contests the propriety of the foreclosure sale itself, arguing that the decree, as administered through the subsequent sale, failed to meet the requirements imposed by law because he was not given due process.Â Â Â  We address the many arguments in support of Brianâ€™s claim separately.
1. Decree
Brian essentially argues that the original foreclosure decree was void because it was somehow altered by the procedures of the subsequent sale.Â  
Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP, provides that a party may seek relief from judgment where the judgment is void.Â  However, the definition of void for Rule 60(b)(4) purposes â€œonly encompasses judgments from courts which failed to provide proper due process, or judgments from courts which lacked subject matter jurisdiction or personal jurisdiction.â€Â  McDaniel v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 324 S.C. 639, 644, 478 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œA judgment is not rendered void by irregularities which do not involve jurisdiction.â€Â  Universal Benefits, Inc. v. McKinney, 349 S.C. 179, 183, 561 S.E.2d 659, 661 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â  
Brian has not offered anything tending to show that the decree of foreclosure was invalid.Â  Brian admits that he had notice of the foreclosure action, the hearing, and the decree.Â  He concedes that he did not appear in the foreclosure action prior to the entry of judgment and that he did not appeal the decree.Â  The evidence in the record shows that due process was given to Brian prior to entry of the decree, and Brian does not challenge the masterâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction over the foreclosure action.Â  Thus, nothing in the record indicates that the decree was a â€œvoidâ€ judgment.Â  Therefore, Brianâ€™s only challenge to the decree would have been pursuant to an appeal.Â  Because he failed to appeal from the decree, the validity of the decree is the law of the case and Brian has waived any right to challenge it. 
2. Foreclosure Sale Violated Due Process
Brian argues the foreclosure sale was void because the lack of notice regarding the withdrawal of the waiver of deficiency amounted to a lack of due process.Â Â Â  
â€œProcedural due process requires notice, the opportunity to be heard in a meaningful way, and judicial review.â€Â  Blanton v. Stathos, 351 S.C. 534, 542, 570 S.E.2d 565, 569 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, there is â€œno requirement of law that parties to a suit for foreclosure be given personal notice of a judicial sale.â€Â  Peoples Fed. Sav. & Loan Assoc. v. Graham, 291 S.C. 178, 182, 352 S.E.2d 511, 514 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  All that is required is that the requirements of law for public notice of judicial sales are met.Â  Id.Â  
Due process requirements were met in this case.Â  Brian does not dispute that he received notice of the hearing and the decree.Â  The sale was properly advertised.Â  He was not entitled to personal notice of the sale.Â  If he had attended the sale, he would have heard the announcement that the deficiency had been waived.Â  Nor was Brian entitled to personal notice of the waiver.Â  No statute or rule imposes such a requirement, and this court is not empowered to append additional requirements to the statutory scheme.Â  See Ex parte Moore, 352 S.C. 508, 511, 575 S.E.2d 561, 562 (2003) (noting that the terms of a judicial sale are controlled by court order, Rule 71, SCRCP, and statute, and finding the imposition of a bright-line 5:00 p.m. deadline on judicial sales was not allowed by statute and should be reversed). 
Scott also claims that his due process rights were violated by the same actions.Â  He claims that he lost the right to redeem the property at its true value and to, consequently, reduce the debt owed to him by Brian.Â Â  
Scott was not a party to the foreclosure action.Â  Instead, he requested to have the Rule 60(b) motion treated as an independent action in equity.Â  â€œA party is not bound by the label he puts on his paper.Â  A motion may be treated as an independent action or vice versa as is appropriate.â€Â  11 Fed. Prac. & Proc. Civ.2d Â§ 2868 (1995).Â  However, Scottâ€™s argument fails because he has no protected interest in the subject property.Â  
To have a property interest triggering due process protection, a person must â€œshow that he was arbitrarily and capriciously deprived of a cognizable property interest rooted in state law.â€Â  Sunset Cay, LLC v. City of Folly Beach, 357 S.C. 414, 430, 593 S.E.2d 462, 470 (2004).Â  Although the record indicates that Scott was the prior owner of the underlying property and conveyed it to Brian, the record does not indicate any terms of the conveyance, including any debt owed by Brian.Â  Even assuming Scott was Brianâ€™s creditor, there is no evidence that Scott had any security interest in the property, or any other interest justifying his inclusion in this proceeding.Â  Therefore, Scott lacks standing to challenge the validity of this foreclosure sale through Rule 60(b).Â  Further, in spite of his lack of standing, Scott received notice of the sale through the advertisement and had the opportunity to bid on the property at that time.Â  
3. Application of Rule 71(b)
Brian argues that the waiver should not have changed the statutory requirement that bidding remain open for thirty days after the sale.Â  He asserts that the master erred in relying upon Rule 71(b) instead of the statutes regarding the procedures at a judicial sale. 
â€œThe terms and conditions of a judicial sale are controlled by court order, Rule 71, SCRCP, and statute.â€Â  Ex parte Moore, 352 S.C. at 510, 575 S.E.2d at 562.Â  The General Assembly provided by statute that in foreclosure sales the bidding must remain open for thirty days after the sale for upset bids.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-720 (2005).Â  However, when the creditorâ€™s complaint states that he is waiving right to a deficiency judgment, the thirty-day requirement does not apply.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-760 (2005).Â  When this occurs, the notice of sale must state that no deficiency judgment has been demanded and therefore the sale will be final as of the date of the foreclosure sale.Â  Id.Â  
Rule 71 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure also addresses the procedure for foreclosure sales.Â  Subsection (b) of that rule provides, in relevant part, as follows:Â  

Unless the pleadings state that no personal or deficiency judgment is demanded or any right to such judgment is expressly waived in writing, the bidding shall not be closed upon the day of sale but shall remain open until the thirtieth day after such sale exclusive of the day of the sale.

Rule 71(b), SCRCP (emphasis added).Â  The enabling legislation for the Rules of Civil Procedure contains a statement of legislative intent that in the event of a conflict between a rule and a procedural statute, the rules should control.Â  Act No. 100 Â§ 3, 1985 S.C. Acts 277. 
Although the statutes appear to require notice of the waiver in the complaint and notice of sale, Rule 71(b) allows waiver to be made in writing and contains no time requirement.Â  In fact, case law prior to the adoption of Rule 71 contemplated that the choice of whether to seek a deficiency judgment need not be made in the complaint.Â  See e.g. Perpetual Bldg. & Loan Assâ€™n of Anderson v. Braun, 270 S.C. 338, 339-40, 242 S.E.2d 407, 407-08 (1978) (holding that the right to seek deficiency judgment is incidental to the mortgage foreclosure and that the language of section 15-39-760 indicates the General Assemblyâ€™s intent to deny a deficiency judgment only when it has been expressly waived).Â  Because the right to seek a deficiency judgment belongs to the creditor, so does the right to waive a deficiency.Â  We do not interpret the statutes as forbidding a creditor to later waive its right to a deficiency if it is not originally done in the pleadings.Â  Thus, allowing a party to waive the right to a deficiency at any time prior to the sale pursuant to Rule 71(b), SCRCP, does not conflict with the statutory procedures regarding foreclosure sales. 
Although Bank of America prayed for a deficiency judgment in the original foreclosure complaint, Bank of America notified the master in writing that it wanted to waive its right to deficiency prior to the sale.Â  Both the decree and the notice of sale provided notice that Bank of America was reserving its right to waive its claim for a deficiency up to the time of sale.Â  All parties involved in this matter and the general public were on notice of the possibility that the foreclosure sale could be final the day of sale if the bank waived its right to a deficiency.Â  Because Bank of America properly notified the master in writing of its waiver of deficiency, the thirty-day requirement did not apply, and the master properly found that the sale was final.
4. Disparity Between Notice of Sale and the Decree
Brian argues that the sale was invalid because the language of the notice of sale varied from the language in the decree.Â  As set forth above, both documents contained language providing for the possibility of a waiver prior to the sale.Â  The decree stated that Bank of America could waive its right to a deficiency â€œin writing prior to the sale.â€Â  However, the notice stated that the bank could waive the deficiency â€œup to and including the date of the sale.â€Â Â Â  
Because we find that Rule 71(b) allows a waiver of deficiency to be made in writing at any time prior to the sale, we find the difference to be immaterial.Â  The inclusion of language providing notice of the possibility of a waiver was consistent with the statutory framework and with Rule 71(b).Â  The master did not abuse his discretion in finding that the difference between â€œprior to the saleâ€ and â€œup to and including the date of the saleâ€ did not result in a lack of notice to Brian or materially prejudice him. 
In summary, we hold that the master did not abuse his discretion in denying the Rule 60(b) motion because Brian cannot meet the standard provided in Mictronics, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 510-11, 548 S.E.2d 223, 226 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Although he promptly sought relief, he has no explanation for the failure to appeal from the decree.Â  The foreclosure sale is not void for lack of due process.Â  Further, the sale is not void due to the timing of the written waiver of deficiency or because the notice of sale language regarding the reservation of the right to waive deficiency was worded differently than from the decree.Â  
IV. Equitable Claims
Brian and Scott argue that their independent action in equity was the proper procedure for Scott, as a non-party to the initial judgment, to challenge the foreclosure sale.Â  They argue that the master erred in denying the independent action in equity because the underlying judgment was the result of mistake.Â  Finally, they assert the master erred in finding the equities favored the Matthews as bona fide purchasers.Â  Although we agree that an independent action in equity is the proper method for a non-party to challenge a judgment, we find that the Wellsâ€™ independent action lacked merit.Â  We agree with the master that the Matthews are bona fide purchasers.
A. Mistake as Grounds for Independent Action in Equity
The ability to seek relief from judgment due to mistake, inadvertence, or excusable neglect pursuant to Rule 60(b) does not limit a courtâ€™s power to â€œentertain an independent action to relieve a party from a judgment, order, or proceeding, or to set aside a judgment for fraud upon the court.â€Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  An independent action in equity is also the proper vehicle through which a non-party to the original action may challenge the prior judgment.Â  First Carolinas Joint Stock Land Bank of Columbia v. Knotts, 191 S.C. 384, 401-02, 1 S.E.2d 797, 805 (1939) (noting that it was appropriate for the bank to bring an independent action in equity to test the propriety of judgments in actions to which it was not a party).Â  A judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction is conclusive as to parties to the action and those in privity and may not be set aside by evidence that it was irregular or improperly obtained.Â  Knotts, 191 S.C. at 401-02, 1 S.E.2d at 805.Â  Moreover, a judgment normally may not be impeached in a separate action unless there is evidence of fraud, collusion, or want of jurisdiction.Â  Id.Â Â  
We do not dispute that a non-party, such as Scott, is entitled to bring an independent action in equity to challenge a judgment.Â  However, we find no merit to Scottâ€™s argument on appeal that he was entitled to relief from the judgment due to mistake.Â  Scottâ€™s argument in support of this issue on appeal is that mistake was alleged in Brianâ€™s motion for relief from judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, and the same reasons apply equally to Scottâ€™s claim.Â  However, Brianâ€™s arguments rely upon â€œexcusable neglectâ€ and Scott does not specify what â€œmistakeâ€ entitled him to relief.Â Â  
To the extent that Scott attempts to argue that the lack of notice of the written waiver of deficiency caused him prejudice, we find the master did not err in denying his independent action for relief from the judgment.Â  As previously discussed, Bank of Americaâ€™s decision to waive its right to a deficiency judgment prior to the foreclosure sale did not violate statutory law and was made pursuant to procedural rules.Â  Further notice was given at the foreclosure sale that it would be final. Â Scottâ€™s failure to appear at the foreclosure sale to place a bid on the property because he mistakenly believed that he would have thirty days after the sale in which to place an upset bid does not amount to a mistake entitling him to relief. 
B. Balancing the Equities
Brian asserts the master erred in finding the Matthews, as purchasers, were entitled to greater protection under equity.Â  Citing Goethe v. Cleland, 323 S.C. 50, 448 S.E.2d 574 (Ct. App. 1994), he argues that the improprieties in handling the sale invalidated the purchasersâ€™ title.
With regard to innocent purchasers, the South Carolina Code provides as follows:

Upon the execution and delivery by the proper officer of the court of a deed for any property sold at a judicial sale under a decree of a court of competent jurisdiction the proceedings under which such sale is made shall be deemed res judicata as to any and all bona fide purchasers for value without notice, notwithstanding such sale may not subsequently be confirmed by the court.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-870 (2005).Â  Generally, public policy requires that â€œthe validity of judicial sales be upheld, if in reason and justice it can be done.â€Â  Cumbie v. Newberry, 251 S.C. 33, 37, 159 S.E.2d 915, 917 (1968).Â  Thus, generally, a â€œpurchaser in good faith at a judicial sale is not affected by irregularities in the proceedings or even error in the judgment,â€ so long as the purchaser made inquiry into the jurisdiction of the court ordering the sale and whether all the proper parties were before the court when the order was made.Â  Id.Â  Thus, while a bona fide purchaser may not have knowledge of irregularities in the procedures, a bona fide purchaser is charged with knowledge of the terms of the judgment.Â  Goethe, 323 S.C. at 55, 448 S.E.2d at 576.Â  
In Goethe, the creditor requested a deficiency judgment in the foreclosure pleadings.Â  However, the order erroneously provided that the sale would be final as of the date of the sale, in violation of the requirement that bidding remain open for thirty days for upset bids.Â  Goethe 323 S.C. at 52, 448 S.E.2d at 575.Â  The property was auctioned under the erroneous order, but the Clerk of Court discovered the error before the buyer could comply with the bid.Â  Consequently, no deed was ever issued.Â  Id. at 55, 448 S.E.2d at 576.Â  This court affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s decision to set aside the sale, noting that the purchaser was not a â€œbona fide purchaser for valueâ€ without notice of the irregularity of the proceedings because: the sale was never completed; the purchaser was charged with notice of the terms of the judgment indicating that the mortgagor sought a deficiency judgment; and the purchaser was charged with the knowledge that the proper procedure when a deficiency is sought is that the bidding remains open for thirty days.Â  Goethe, 323 S.C. at 55, 448 S.E.2d at 576-77.
The facts in the present case are distinguishable.Â  As previously discussed, the correct procedures were followed regarding notice of the final sale and waiver of the deficiency. Â The notice of sale and the decree both indicated that Bank of America could choose to waive the right to a deficiency.Â  The master announced at the sale that the deficiency judgment was waived and the sale would be final.Â  Thus, there were no irregularities that would affect the judicial sale.Â  Further, a deed was delivered to the Matthews.Â  We find no error with the masterâ€™s determination that the Matthews were bona fide purchasers without notice. 
CONCLUSION
We hold that Brian has failed to demonstrate excusable neglect or mistake sufficient for relief from a judgment under Rule 60(b).Â  We further hold that Brian has waived any right to contest the decree under Rule 60(b) by failing to appeal, and that Bank of Americaâ€™s written waiver without notice to Brian did not violate either Brianâ€™s or Scottâ€™s due process rights because the waiver was proper under Rule 71(b) and notice to other parties is not required by law.Â  We find no material disparity between the terms of the decree and the notice of sale.Â  Additionally, we find no mistake that would justify granting relief to Scott in his independent action in equity.Â  Finally, we hold that even if the sale were conducted improperly, it may not be set aside because the Matthews are good faith purchasers for value without notice.Â  Accordingly the order of the master is hereby
 AFFIRMED. 
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  It appears that Scott was the prior owner of the property and conveyed it to Brian on March 2, 1998.Â  However, nothing in the record indicates the terms of the conveyance.Â  
[2]Â  Brian and Scott allege in their brief that the mortgage was actually executed in 1996.Â  The mortgage documents in the record show a date of March 12, 1998, and the master held in his decree that the mortgage was executed on that date.Â  Neither Brian nor Scott argues on appeal that the master erred in finding the mortgage was executed on March 12, 1998.Â  Thus, that finding is the law of the case.
[3]Â  Although only Brian was a party to the foreclosure action and the motion for relief from judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, it appears from the Wellsâ€™ brief that Scott is joining in on all of Brianâ€™s arguments.Â  As will be discussed more fully below, because Scott was only a party to the separate action in equity, only his arguments on appeal relating to the separate equity action will be addressed.

Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Stanley Hall pled guilty to kidnapping and pointing and presenting a firearm.Â  He argues his sentence is unconstitutionally disproportionate to his crime.Â  His counsel attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating she reviewed the record and concluded Hallâ€™s appeal is without merit.Â  Hall did not file a pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
 APPEAL DISMISSED.[1]
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Robert E. Hill,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Virginia C. Harbert,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-283
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 20, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael Stephen Chambers, of Greenville, for Appellant.Â  
Lynn Reames Hudson and Melvin R. Hutson, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert E. Hill appeals the trial courtâ€™s dissolution of his partnership with Virginia C. Harbert and the apportionment of partnership proceeds.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1998, Hill and Harbert formed a partnership to purchase residential homes at foreclosure sales, renovate them, and sell them for profit.Â  Under their oral partnership agreement, Hill was to locate the houses and oversee their remodeling and renovation.Â  Harbert was to arrange for or provide the financing.Â  
In practice, however, the partnership quickly developed into a one-person operation with Harbert handling many of Hillâ€™s assigned responsibilities.Â  Harbert incurred the expense of hiring an employee to supervise renovations.Â  Additionally, Harbert became concerned Hill was using partnership assets for his personal business.Â  
Due to Hillâ€™s actions, Harbert â€œfiredâ€ him in August 2000.Â  Hill retained tools and a pick-up truck purchased for use in partnership ventures.Â  Harbert continued to make payments on the truck, but Hill abandoned it in Tennessee with extensive damage to the exterior and electrical system.Â  
In an effort to wind up the partnership, Harbert incurred additional expenses to repair the vehicle so it could be sold.Â  Harbert also completed renovations and sold three homes owned by the partnership.Â  
Hill sued Harbert in 2001 seeking judicial dissolution of the partnership and an accounting of partnership assets.Â  Hill also alleged breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment.Â  
 The trial court held a bifurcated trial, found a partnership existed, ordered the partnership dissolved, and granted judgment for Harbert in the amount of $10,255.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A case with legal and equitable issues presents a divided scope of review.Â  Kuznik v. Bees Ferry Assocs., 342 S.C. 579, 589, 538 S.E.2d 15, 20 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  When legal and equitable actions are maintained in one suit, each retains its own identity as legal or equitable for purposes of the applicable standard of review on appeal.Â  Corley v. Ott, 326 S.C. 89, 92, 485 S.E.2d 97, 99 (1997). 
An action for damages arising from breach of fiduciary duty is at law, but the suit must sound in equity if equitable relief is sought.Â  Bivens v. Watkins, 313 S.C. 228, 230, 437 S.E.2d 132, 133 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  In an action at law, the trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact will be upheld unless without evidentiary support.Â  Corley, 326 S.C. at 92, 485 S.E.2d at 99.
An action for an accounting of a partnership is equitable.Â  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  On appeal, the appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Fiduciary Duty
Hill asserts the trial court erred in finding Harbert did not breach her fiduciary duties.Â  Hill specifically complains that Harbertâ€™s management of the partnership assets and bookkeeping constituted a breach.Â  We disagree.
A partnership imposes a fiduciary relationship upon individuals who are obligated to refrain from taking advantage of one another by even the slightest misrepresentation or concealment.Â  Lawson v. Rogers, 312 S.C. 492, 498-99, 435 S.E.2d 853, 857 (1993).Â  A fiduciary relationship imposes mutual duties of loyalty, good faith, and fair dealing.Â  Id.  
â€œParties in a fiduciary relationship must fully disclose to each other all known information that is significant and material, and when this duty to disclose is triggered, silence may constitute fraud.â€Â  Ellie v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 100, 594 S.E.2d 485, 497 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Anthony v. Padmar, Inc., 320 S.C. 436, 449, 465 S.E.2d 745, 752 (Ct. App. 1995)).
The behavior of a partner is not governed by marketplace principles or with an eye to personal advantage, but to universally recognized obligations of loyalty, good faith, and fair dealing between partners.Â  See Few v. Few, 239 S.C. 321, 336, 122 S.E.2d 829, 836 (1961); Moore v. Moore, 360 S.C. 241, 251, 599 S.E.2d 467, 472 (Ct. App. 2004); see also 59A Am. Jur. 2d Partnership Â§ 420 (1987).
A partnership may be dissolved, but those fiduciary duties continue to exist during the winding up period when the partnership affairs are completed.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-920 (Supp. 2004).Â  If a partnership agreement does not stipulate an ending date, then the partnership is an agreement at will, subject to dissolution by the act of one or more partners.Â  McPherson v. J.E. Sirrine & Co., 206 S.C. 183, 208, 33 S.E.2d 501, 511 (1945); see also 59A Am. Jur. 2d Partnership Â§ 819 (1987).
Hill offered no evidence to demonstrate Harbert denied him access to partnership accounts or records or prohibited him from participating in the management of the business.Â  To the contrary, Hill admitted on cross-examination that he had access to the partnership books.Â  The record reveals the partnership began with the parties collaborating to share responsibilities and declined to the point that Hill became an inactive member who caused conflict with members of the work crew when he did choose to participate.Â  
Harbert acted within her rights as a partner to terminate the partnership.Â  Harbert also acted properly to begin the process of winding up the partnership affairs by renovating and selling the partnershipâ€™s remaining assets.Â  
II.Â  Partnership Funds
Hill argues the trial court erred by finding he failed to establish the amount of partnership funds Harbert allegedly spent without authority.Â  We disagree.
Hill alleges Harbert spent partnership funds on renovating two properties that were not owned by the partnership.Â  Hill acknowledged Harbert maintained meticulous accounting records.Â  Hill was unable to demonstrate that either of the two properties was renovated with partnership funds.Â  A plaintiff has the burden of proof on allegations raised in his pleadings.Â  See Smith v. Smith, 50 S.C. 54, 65, 27 S.E. 545, 550-51 (1897) (finding moving party in an equity action has burden of proving he was aggrieved and party must provide more than mere allegations in the pleadings).Â  Hill failed to provide any evidence that Harbert spent partnership funds on non-partnership properties.
We therefore affirm the trial court in its determination that Hill failed to prove the amount of partnership funds, if any, spent by Harbert in an allegedly unauthorized manner.
III.Â  Apportionment
Hill asserts the trial court erroneously apportioned the partiesâ€™ assets and liabilities based on the parties respective conduct as well as their relative contributions to the business.Â  We disagree.
On dissolution of a partnership, each partner has an equal right to possession of partnership property and assets, as they are joint property of the partners.Â  59A Am. Jur. 2d Partnership Â§ 894 (1987).
We note the parties stipulated the trial court could apportion partnership property in an equitable manner, a manner that necessitates weighing the behavior and actions of the parties.Â  We are mindful of the deference we give to the trial court who was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the parties and their witnesses.Â  See Townes Assocs., 266 S.C. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 775.Â  Moreover, our own review of the record indicates the trial court had ample evidence to support its conclusion that Hill owed Harbert $10,225 in partnership proceeds.Â  
Hill maintained exclusive possession of several partnership assets including tools and a company truck.Â  Hill violated his duty to the partnership by abandoning the truck in another state in such a deteriorated condition that it had to undergo extensive repairs before it could be sold.Â  As the trial court correctly noted:Â  â€œWhat [Hill] ignores is the obligation to use partnership property in good faith and in furtherance of the partnership business.â€Â  
Accordingly, we conclude the trial court did not err in its apportionment of partnership assets and liabilities.Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Â  Data Search, Inc. appeals the master in equityâ€™s order finding it liable for damages to Money First Financial Services for providing incorrect title information related to a mortgage loan closing.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In March 2000, W.E. and Lois Montgomery sought to refinance their existing mortgage with Money First.Â  Money First contracted with Data Search to perform a title search of the Montgomerysâ€™ property and assist in the loan closing.Â  Money First chose Data Search due to the previous work it had done as an agent for Stewart Title Guaranty Company in connection with the Montgomerysâ€™ existing mortgage that was closed in 1999.Â  Money First retained Stewart Title to issue a title insurance policy.Â  
Data Search in turn employed a title abstractor to research the title and, following the closing, record the mortgage.Â  This was the same abstractor who examined the title and issued a report on the 1999 mortgage.Â  In 1999 and 2000, the abstractorâ€™s report noted the Montgomerys only had a life estate in their land.Â  
In updating her 1999 report for the 2000 loan, the abstractor informed Data Search they had incorrectly reported the Montgomerys owned the property in fee simple.Â  A Data Search representative informed the abstractor that Data Searchâ€™s records indicated the Montgomerys owned the property as tenants in common, and the representative instructed the abstractor to record the mortgage.Â  
Prior to closing, Stewart Title issued a title commitment through Data Search, its agent, which stated the Montgomerys owned the subject property in fee simple.Â  Data Search served as closing agent for the loan and issued a first lien title clearance letter that failed to inform Money First of the true state of the Montgomerysâ€™ ownership interest.Â  Both the title commitment and final title policy issued by Data Search stated the Montgomerys held a fee simple interest in the property.Â  Money First loaned a substantial sum in reliance on Data Searchâ€™s assertions regarding the extent of the Montgomerysâ€™ ownership of the property.Â  
After closing, Money First assigned its mortgage to Key Bank.Â  The Montgomerys subsequently defaulted on the loan.Â  Key Bank began foreclosure proceedings and, as a result, learned the true status of the Montgomerysâ€™ title.Â  Due to the error, Money First was obligated to repurchase the mortgage from Key Bank.Â  
Money First commenced a foreclosure action on the mortgage and sought damages against Data Search and Stewart Title for breach of contract as well as negligence.Â  The master bifurcated the matter and issued an order of foreclosure that resulted in a public sale, at which the highest bid was $4,001.Â  Money First received a deficiency judgment of $133,112.54.Â  
The master found the value of the mobile home and property would be $23,000 had the title been as reported by Data Search.Â  The master further found the value of the mobile home and property with the title as it actually existed to be $4,000.Â  The master ordered Stewart Title to pay Money First damages in the amount of the value of the property as reported, less the actual value of the land, or $19,000.Â  
The master further found Data Search breached its contract and was negligent in failing to disclose the true status of the Montgomerysâ€™ title, reasoning that Money First relied on Data Searchâ€™s misrepresentations and as a result incurred damages of $133,112.54.Â  The master ordered Data Search to pay that amount as the foreseeable damages resulting from its misrepresentations.Â  Data Search appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A case asserting breach of contract and seeking money damages is an action at law.Â  Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 483, 486 S.E.2d 771, 773 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  An appellate court will not disturb the findings of fact of a judge, sitting without a jury in an action at law, unless those findings are without evidentiary support.Â  Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of California, 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).[1]
LAW/ANALYSIS
Data Search asserts the master in equity failed to apply the proper measure of damages and thus erred in ordering it to pay damages of $133,112.54.Â  Data Search argues the correct measure of damages is the difference between the fair market value of the property without the title defect and the fair market value of the property with title as it actually existed.Â  We disagree.
â€œIn a breach of contract action, damages serve to place the nonbreaching party in the position he would have enjoyed had the contract been performed.â€Â  South Carolina Fed. Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby Dev. Co., 303 S.C. 74, 77, 399 S.E.2d 8, 10-11 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  Normally damages â€œconsist of two distinct elements:Â  (1) out-of-pocket costs actually incurred as a result of the contract; and (2) the gain above costs that would have been realized had the contract been performed.â€Â  Id. at 11, 399 S.E.2d at 77.
A party proves damages by showing an actual loss that would not have been incurred but for the defendantâ€™s breach of the contract.Â  Drews Co. v. Ledwith-Wolfe Assocs., 296 S.C. 207, 213, 371 S.E.2d 532, 535 (1988).Â  In addition, a plaintiff must demonstrate any loss was a natural and foreseeable consequence of the breach that had been reasonably contemplated by the parties at the time the contract was made.Â  Id.
Money First contracted with Data Search to determine the extent of the Montgomerysâ€™ interest in the property.Â  Data Search further agreed to act as the closing agent.Â  In that capacity, Data Search was instructed to close the transaction only if the Montgomerys could grant Money First a first mortgage security lien on the property, and on the condition that a policy of title insurance was issued in keeping with the loan commitment.Â  
Data Search breached its contractual obligations at numerous points.Â  It erroneously reported the state of the title in the initial title commitment and in the first lien title clearance letter completed after closing.Â  Data Search directed its agent to record the mortgage even after the title examiner advised the company that the Montgomerys only possessed a life estate interest in the land.
Data Searchâ€™s principal breach was in failing to notify Money First of the true nature of the title.Â  Data Searchâ€™s actions were to its own benefit, but to Money Firstâ€™s detriment.Â  The record demonstrates Money First would neither have funded the mortgage initially nor been required to repurchase it had Data Search not breached its contractual obligations.Â  
Money First demonstrated it was foreseeable it would incur the damages awarded by relying on Data Searchâ€™s intentional misrepresentations.Â  Simply put, Money First would not have incurred $133,112.54 in damages but for Data Searchâ€™s breach.Â  Accordingly, the master in equity correctly ordered an amount of damages that placed Money First in the same position it was in before the transaction occurred.Â  
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] There is some confusion in the record as to whether this was an action based on negligence or contract.Â  For purposes of this appeal, it makes no difference, for the measure of damages would be the same in either case.Â

title: SCE&G v. Aiken Electric Cooperative
text:
FACTS


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Electric & Gas Co., Appellant,
v.
Aiken Electric Cooperative, Inc., and The South Carolina Public Service Commission, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-292
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Catherine Derrick Taylor, Francis P. Mood, Dalhi N. Myers, and Sarah P. Spruill, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Fred David Butler, Marcus A. Manos, and J. David Black, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal arises from a dispute between South Carolina Electric and Gas (SCE&G) and Aiken Electric Cooperative (Co-op) over the right to serve electricity to a newly constructed school.Â  The South Carolina Public Service Commission (PSC) and circuit court found in favor of the Co-op.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1993, Lexington School District Number 4 acquired a large tract of unimproved property located on Highway 321.Â  This property is within territory assigned to SCE&G for electrical service by the PSC.Â  However, a portion of the property is located within a 300-foot corridor the Co-op is entitled to serve pursuant to section 58-27-620(1)(d)(iii) of the South Carolina CodeÂ  (1977).Â  
In 1999, the school district decided to build Sandhills School, a combined elementary and intermediate school, on the property.Â  Both SCE&G and the Co-op submitted proposals to provide electrical service to the school.Â  The Co-opâ€™s proposal explained that a portion of the structure needed to be built within the 300-foot corridor in order for it to provide service to the school.Â  The school district accepted the Co-opâ€™s bid and to comply with their request, constructed a storage and maintenance facility within the Co-opâ€™s 300-foot corridor.Â  
The main building is constructed outside of the 300-foot corridor, and the Co-op did not deliver electricity directly to the storage and maintenance facility within its 300-foot corridor.Â  Rather, in order to comply with sound and safe engineering practices, the Co-op delivered service directly to the main school building and transmitted energy back to the maintenance and storage facility.Â  Â Â 
On May 15, 2000, SCE&G filed a complaint before the PSC arguing that it had the exclusive right to serve the Sandhills School.Â  On May 3, 2002, the PSC approved the Co-opâ€™s provision of service to the school.Â  After SCE&Gâ€™s motion for reconsideration was denied, it appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the PSCâ€™s decision.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe Public Service Commission is recognized as the â€˜expertâ€™ designated by the legislature to make policy determinations regarding utility rates; thus, the role of a court reviewing such decisions is very limited.â€Â  GTE Sprint Communications Corp. v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 288 S.C. 174, 179, 341 S.E.2d 126, 128-29 (1986).Â  The appellate courts employ â€œa deferential standard of review when reviewing a decision of the Public Service Commission and will affirm that decision when substantial evidence supports it.â€Â  Duke Power Co. v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 343 S.C. 554, 558, 541 S.E.2d 250, 252 (2001).Â  This court may not substitute its judgment for the commissionâ€™s, especially on questions where there is room for a difference of opinion.Â  Id.Â  â€œBecause the Commissionâ€™s findings are presumptively correct, the party challenging a Commission order bears the burden of convincingly proving the decision is clearly erroneous, or arbitrary or capricious, or an abuse of discretion, in view of the substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  Id.Â  Additionally, the PSC is traditionally given, just as any other agency, respectful consideration in their interpretation of a statute.Â  Nucor Steel v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 310 S.C. 539, 543, 426 S.E.2d 319, 321 (1992).Â  â€œWhere an agency is charged with the execution of a statute, the agencyâ€™s interpretation should not be overruled without cogent reason.â€Â  Id.
LAW / ANALYSIS
SCE&G argues, based on legislative intent and the potential for absurd results, that the only sound reading of section 58-27-610(2) of the South Carolina Code (1977) requires that electricity actually be delivered within the 300-foot corridor.Â  We disagree.
According to the plain meaning rule of statutory interpretation, it is not the courtâ€™s place to change the meaning of a clear and unambiguous statute.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  â€œWhere the statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€Â  Id. Â Section 58-27-620(1)(d) of the South Carolina Code (1977) provides:Â  

With respect to service in all areas outside the corporate limits of municipalities, electric suppliers shall have rights and be subject to restrictions as follows: (1) Every electric supplier shall have the right to serve: . . . (d) If chosen by the consumer, any premises initially requiring electric service after July 1, 1969, (i) Which are located wholly or partially within three hundred feet of the lines of such electric supplier and also wholly or partially within three hundred feet of the lines of another electric supplier, as each of such supplierâ€™s lines exist on July 1, 1969 or as extended to serve consumers that the supplier has the right to serve or as acquired after July 1, 1969.

(Emphasis added.)
A plain reading of section 58-27-620 shows it is applicable to the case at hand.Â  The first two requirements are metâ€”the school required service after July 1, 1969 and chose the Co-op.Â  Additionally, the premises are located â€œpartiallyâ€ within 300 feet of the Co-opâ€™s lines.Â  This plain reading is buttressed by the substantial deference afforded the decisions made by agencies entrusted with the task of interpreting statutes.Â  Nucor, 310 S.C. at 545, 426 S.E.2d at 321.Â  The PSC interpreted section 58-27-620 in just this manner in a prior decision.Â  In that case, the PSC ruled, inter alia, that a portico and covered driveway located within 300 feet of an existing line supported the right to provide electrical service to a main hospital and medical building.Â  In re Hartsville H.M.A., Inc., Order No. 98-450 (Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n June 16, 1998).Â  
However, SCE&G argues the court must examine the definition of â€œpremises.â€Â  â€œPremisesâ€ is defined in 58-27-610(2) as:Â  

[T]he building, structure or facility to which electricity is being or is to be furnished; provided, that two or more buildings, structures or facilities which are located on one tract or contiguous tracts of land and are utilized by one electric consumer for farming, business, commercial, industrial, institutional or governmental purposes, shall together constitute one â€˜premises,â€™ except that any such building, structure or facility shall not, together with any other building, structure or facility, constitute one â€œpremisesâ€ if the electric service to it is separately metered and the charges for such service are calculated independently of charges for service to any other building, structure or facility.

(Emphasis added.)
Specifically, SCE&G argues the phrase â€œto which electricity is being or is to be furnishedâ€ is not precisely defined.Â  They argue two interpretations existâ€”that the electricity be â€œultimately providedâ€ or alternatively â€œactually deliveredâ€ to a building within the electric supplierâ€™s assigned territory.Â  SCE&G suggests the Co-opâ€™s argument is that the statute merely requires an electric supplier to â€œultimately provideâ€ electricity to a building at least partially within its 300-foot corridor.Â  
SCE&G urges the adoption of the â€œactual deliveryâ€ interpretation and supports its argument with potential scenarios regarding provider overreach.Â  However, section 58-27-620 specifically addresses the right of a provider to supply a premises if it is â€œlocated wholly or partiallyâ€ within the corridor.Â  Section 58-27-610 also broadly defines â€œpremisesâ€ so that it can include more than one building and more than one tract of land.Â  This language demonstrates the legislatureâ€™s intention to read this exception and the underlying term broadly.Â  Thus, it is logical to conclude that this broad legislative intent should be extended to the phrase â€œto which electricity is being or is to be furnished,â€ especially when we give an agency substantial deference in its interpretation of a statute.Â  
SCE&G also argues the intent of the legislation was to avoid higher costs and duplication of infrastructure.Â  While the Co-op has upgraded its lines to provide service to the school and also constructed new lines outside of its corridor in order to serve the school, we do not find that the statute prohibits these activities if they are undertaken to serve a premises the Co-op is entitled to serve under section 58-27-620. 
Finally, SCE&G argues the PSCâ€™s interpretation of section 58-27-620 could lead to absurd results.Â  It uses an apartment complex example to illustrate this contention.Â  SCE&G contends it would allow the Co-op to deliver power to a master-metered apartment complex outside its service territory if some power was routed back to a security station at the apartmentâ€™s entrance, which was within the Co-opâ€™s service area.Â  However, this broad reading of section 58-27-620 is checked by the definition of â€œpremises.â€Â  That definition states no building or group of buildings can constitute a single premises, â€œif the electric service to it is separately metered and the charges for such service are calculated independently of charges for service to any other building, structure or facility.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-27-610(2) (1977).Â  This would prevent an apartment complex from being only partially located within the corridor because it would be unusual if the buildings were not separately metered and the charges calculated independently.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed above, the circuit courtâ€™s ruling is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., WILLIAMS, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.
