THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Cynthia Goethe Norman, Maurice Carter and John Doe, and Child: Justice Renee Goethe DOB: July 2, 2001, Child: Justin Elijah Goethe DOB: July 2, 2001,       
Defendants,
Of whom Cynthia Goethe Norman is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-293
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 25, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bert Glenn Utsey, III, of Walterboro, for Appellant.
Mark Shelton Moore, of Walterboro, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Cynthia Goethe Norman appeals the family courtâ€™s termination of her parental rights.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Norman is the mother of seven children, with those children having three different biological fathers.Â  Justin and Justice Goethe, the children involved in this action, are twins born on July 2, 2001, and are the children of Norman and Maurice Carter.Â  The Department of Social Services (DSS) removed Justin and Justice from Normanâ€™s home on September 12, 2001, after receiving a report that Justice had ingested a bobby pin.Â  Pursuant to a family court order dated January 9, 2002, the children have remained in foster care.Â  
On April 22, 2002, DSS filed this action for termination of Normanâ€™s parental rights to Justin and Justice alleging numerous grounds, among them that Norman had failed to remedy the conditions that caused DSS to remove the children and that it was not reasonably likely that her home could be made safe within twelve months. [2]   
The family court held a final hearing on January 21, 2003.Â  By order dated February 17, 2003, the family court terminated Normanâ€™s parental rights pursuant to South Carolina Code section 20-7-1572(2) because she was not able to remedy within a reasonable period of time the conditions prompting the childrenâ€™s removal.[3]Â  Norman filed a timely motion to alter or amend the judgment, which the family court denied. 
This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Norman alleges the family court erred in finding there was clear and convincing evidence that she failed to remedy the conditions warranting the removal of Justin and Justice.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Code section 20-7-1572 allows the family court to terminate parental rights upon a finding of one or more of several enumerated grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child.[4]Â  Section 20-7-1572(2) permits termination if:

The child has been removed from the parent pursuant to Section 20-7-610 or Section 20-7-736, has been out of the home for a period of six months following the adoption of a placement plan by court order or by agreement between the department and the parent, and the parent has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal.[5]

The family court found â€œthe minor children have lived outside the residence of their mother . . . since September 12, 2001.â€Â  The family court based removal of Justice and Justin from Normanâ€™s care on physical neglect and the threat of harm to the children.Â  Moreover, the family court found â€œthe home of [Norman] cannot be made appropriate within a reasonable length of time despite reasonable and meaningful efforts on the part of [DSS] to offer appropriate rehabilitat[ive] services.â€Â  Accordingly, the family court held â€œbecause [Norman] has not been able to remedy conditions which made removal necessary, the Court finds that termination of her parental rights is authorized pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(2).â€Â  
We agree with the family courtâ€™s termination of Normanâ€™s parental rights and will not substitute our judgment for that of the family court, which was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.[6]Â  Moreover, the evidence at the termination hearing supports the family courtâ€™s finding that Norman was unable to make her home appropriate within a reasonable length of time despite reasonable and meaningful attempts by DSS to provide assistance.
The children were in the custody of DSS for the sixteen months before the final hearing.Â  Sandy Polk, a foster care supervisor with DSS, testified that none of Normanâ€™s seven children were in her physical custody when this case came to trial.Â  All the children had been placed with new families or were in foster care.[7]Â  In describing her concern about Normanâ€™s parenting skills, Polk related a incident occurring while Norman was visiting with one of her other children during which the child placed a screw in his mouth and Norman attempted to extricate it with a coat hanger.Â  In addition, Normanâ€™s husband testified he had a friend stay with Norman 75 per cent of the time to help her manage her children when they were in her care.Â  
Additionally, Norman has a nomadic history, moving as often as fifteen times to live with either family or friends.Â  Immediately prior to the termination hearing, Norman and her husband faced eviction from their home and, as a result, voluntarily surrendered two other children to DSS.Â  Norman often failed to cooperate with DSS by moving from residence to residence and failing to notify DSS of her relocations.Â  Although Normanâ€™s present husband provided some measure of stability, it is undisputed that, shortly before the hearing, both he and Norman were arrested for criminal domestic violence following an altercation between them.Â  
Polk further testified Norman had a history of mental health problems stemming from diagnoses of schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder.[8]Â  Although Polk acknowledged that Norman had been treated for this problem, Polk further stated that Norman was following through with the treatment only â€œinconsistently.â€Â  When pressed to answer whether she felt that Normanâ€™s condition had improved to the point where she would no longer be a threat to the children, Polk replied only that, although she hoped that was the case, she could not provide assurance that Norman would not be a danger to her children.Â  In response to a question from Normanâ€™s attorney as to whether Normanâ€™s home could be made safe within twelve months, Polk replied that it could be an â€œinnumerable amount of monthsâ€ and that â€œthe parents are no more stable today, as I sit here, to take these children than they were when they were removed.â€
Considering the foregoing in view of the time the children have spent in foster care, we affirm the family courtâ€™s termination of Normanâ€™s parental rights to Justin and Justice pursuant to South Carolina Code section 20-7-1572(2).Â  We nevertheless take this opportunity to extend our gratitude to Normanâ€™s counsel for his vigorous efforts on behalf of his court-appointed client during both the family court proceedings and this appeal.
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in deciding the issue on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The complaint also alleged failure to visit and failure to support as grounds for termination; however, DSS acknowledged at the final hearing that Norman had exercised visitation and provided support according to her means.Â  
[3] The family court also terminated the parental rights of Maurice Carter.Â  Carter did not appeal the termination.
[4]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2004).Â  In her brief, Norman challenges only the finding that she had not remedied the conditions that prompted the removal of the children.
[5]Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-1572(2).
[6]Â  See Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating that, although this court has jurisdiction to find facts according to its own view of the evidence, â€œ[w]e are not required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimonyâ€).Â  
[7]Â  All seven children have been the subjects of some DSS action at various times in their lives.Â  Moreover, Normanâ€™s parental rights to two of her other children were terminated in March 2001.
[8]Â  Because of her condition, Norman was appointed a guardian ad litem.Â  At the beginning of the hearing, the guardian ad litem advised the family court that Norman was not receiving any mental health services and that she did not feel she needed any such services.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Dorothy J. Mabe,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Larry Mabe,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge
Brooks P. Goldsmith, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-294
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 25, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas F. McDow, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
Richard G. Dâ€™Agostino, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this divorce action, Larry Mabe (Husband) appeals the inclusion of certain assets in the marital estate, the apportionment of the marital property, the grant of alimony to Dorothy Mabe (Wife), and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married in 1983 and separated in 2000.Â  Both parties had been married previously.Â  Wife was 65 years old and Husband was 62 at the time of trial.Â  Both parties are currently disabled and on fixed incomes.Â  Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income is $1,302.00 and Wifeâ€™s gross monthly income is $559.00.Â  They do not have any children together. 
At the time of the marriage, Wife owned a 1979 Pontiac Sunbird and some clothes.Â  About a year later, Wife received approximately $17,000.00 from the sale of the marital home from her first marriage.Â  Wife invested the money in annuities and listed Husband as the beneficiary.Â  
Husband and Wife moved into a house Husband owned in Clover, South Carolina.Â  At the time of the marriage, Husband also owned real property in Belmont, North Carolina, and York County, South Carolina, as well as several vehicles, a 401-K pension plan, and a tax-deferred savings plan through his employer, General Electric.Â  
After Wife received the sales proceeds from her former home, the parties signed an â€œAgreementâ€ regarding their property.Â  The agreement recited that their respective assets were separately owned and stated that their â€œagreement now is that whatâ€™s hers will be hers, and whatâ€™s his will continue to be his.â€Â  Although both parties signed the agreement voluntarily, neither party sought independent legal advice and a single attorney prepared the document.Â  
The couple subsequently moved to a home Husband owned debt-free in Belmont, North Carolina.Â  They renovated the home, and Wife helped with painting, putting up paneling, and installing insulation.Â  Wife also worked in the yard.Â  Husband was the primary wage earner, bringing in 91.32 per cent of the coupleâ€™s income during the course of the marriage.Â  
Husband eventually sold everything except a 1977 Ford Truck, a 1969 Chevrolet Nova, and an acre of land with a garage on it.Â  Husband and Wife had a joint checking account together.Â  When Husband sold one of his properties, he deposited the proceeds into the joint checking account and he and Wife â€œenjoyed the money together.â€Â  When the parties sold the marital home in Belmont, they used the proceeds, along with the proceeds of several other investments, on a truck and camper.Â  The couple lived in the camper and traveled together.Â  The camper was titled in Husbandâ€™s name, but Wife believed the parties owned it together.Â  
Later, Husband and Wife returned to Clover, where they built a garage apartment.Â  Wife helped with the construction.Â  The parties lost most of their assets through bad investments.Â  They also spent some of the money.Â  
Husband left Wife one day while she was at church.Â  Husband took the truck and camper, leaving Wife with only her car.Â  Wife was forced to go live with her daughter.Â  Husband allowed Wife to retrieve her personal belongings from the camper thirty days later with a police escort.Â  Husband later changed the locks.Â  Husband testified he left because Wifeâ€™s daughter was addicted to drugs and sometimes homeless or in prison for extended periods, obligating Wife and Husband to care for Wifeâ€™s daughter and her children.Â  
After Husband left, Wife filed for divorce.Â  Husband refused to accept service, and subsequently served divorce papers on Wife from Tennessee.Â  Wife hired an attorney in Tennessee and incurred $660.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees to obtain a dismissal of that action.Â  Husband then filed an answer and counterclaim to Wifeâ€™s action. Â 
The family court issued a temporary order in which Husband was ordered to pay $350.00 per month for spousal support.Â  Husband subsequently dropped insurance coverage on the camper, and the camper was apparently stolen shortly thereafter.Â  Husband then went to live in the garage apartment. 
After a trial on the merits, the family court issued an order granting the divorce and awarding $250.00 per month in permanent periodic alimony to Wife, making an equitable distribution of the marital property, and awarding Wife $4,500.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Husband argues the agreement he and Wife signed shortly after they married and their actions during their marriage â€œprove an intent to maintain the separate property of each.â€Â  We disagree.Â  
Property may be excluded from the marital estate by written contract executed either before or after the marriage.[2]Â  To be presumed fair and equitable, however, a contract must meet several requirements.Â  The parties must have executed the contract voluntarily, with both parties represented by separate counsel.[3]Â  Additionally, full financial disclosure must be provided to each party, including information as to income, debts, and assets.[4]Â  
We agree with the family courtâ€™s finding that the agreement in this case did not meet these requirements.Â  It is undisputed the parties were not separately represented by counsel.Â  Moreover, although Husband alleged on appeal that both parties were aware of each otherâ€™s assets, Wife testified that neither party made any financial disclosure.Â  In our view, then, the family court correctly determined that the agreement only evidenced the partiesâ€™ intent to keep their non-marital property separate and did not address the ownership of property acquired during the marriage after the execution of the agreement. 
We further agree with Wifeâ€™s argument that, notwithstanding the partiesâ€™ intent about their separate property when they signed the agreement, their combined actions and conduct throughout the marriage evidenced a different intent.[5]Â  
Husband asserts the family court erred in finding the proceeds from the sale of his non-marital assets became transmuted simply by placement into the joint banking account.Â  We, however, do not interpret the appealed order to make this finding; rather, the family court determined these funds lost their non-marital character not only because they were deposited into the joint account into which Wife deposited her earnings, but also because they were co-mingled with marital funds and because Husband was unable to strictly account for them.Â  We find no error in this conclusion.[6]
When the Clover property was sold, part of the proceeds went to renovate the Belmont property, where the couple lived for some time.Â  Wife helped with the renovation efforts.Â  Some of the proceeds went toward the purchase of the garage package and generator, which the parties used in support of the marriage.Â  Again, Wife helped with the construction efforts.Â  Additional proceeds went into an account with Fortis Investors; however, the Fortis account was also funded with money from the joint checking account, to which both parties had access and which both parties used.Â  Finally, Husband acknowledged that he and Wife simply spent a part of the proceeds of the Clover property.Â  
The proceeds of the sale of the Belmont home were likewise untraceable.Â  Some of the proceeds were invested in the Briar Cliff RV Resort and later used to purchase the camper and truck as well as the kit to build the garage apartment.Â  Although the camper was acquired partly through the trade-in of non-marital property belonging to Husband, we hold the record supports the family courtâ€™s finding that the truck and camper were marital property.Â  Husband and Wife purchased the camper for their joint use.Â  Some of Wifeâ€™s disability income was used toward the purchase, and Wife testified she understood that they were buying it jointly.Â  The truck was used to haul the camper and for other marital purposes.Â  Even Husband admitted that â€œwe went truck shopping.â€Â  The parties lived in the camper for some time and traveled extensively.Â  
When Husband sold the nine-acre parcel in York County, he provided the financing to the buyer at twelve per cent interest.Â  Husband admitted that he and Wife enjoyed the proceeds together.Â  
Husband also had substantial assets in the form of a General Electric savings plan.Â  To the extent contributions were made during the marriage, these funds were marital property.[7]Â  From this, Husband invested a substantial amount with Alliance Leasing.Â  When Alliance Leasing went bankrupt, Husband received approximately $53,000.00, which he placed into a Wachovia account in his name.Â  Wife also separately invested her own funds with Alliance leasing, from which she got back only about $600.00.Â  When the parties divorced, only $32,000.00 remained in this account.Â  The family court found that Husband had not met his burden of showing the extent to which funds from the account constituted non-marital property.Â  We concur.Â  Nothing in the record provides information necessary to make such a determination. 
Husband further argues that the family court should not have held him accountable for the loss of the camper.Â  We find no error.Â  The temporary order enjoined both parties from â€œdisposing of, conveying out, transferring, secreting, or hiding any marital assets.â€Â  After the temporary order, husband cancelled the insurance on the camper.Â  Husband testified that shortly thereafter, the camper was stolen and he received no insurance proceeds from the loss.Â  We see no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision.Â  It would be inequitable to punish Wife for Husbandâ€™s failure to maintain the insurance policy, particularly when, as here, Husband took the camper when he left the marriage, resulting in Wife having no place no live.[8]  
2.Â  Husband next argues that, because he made most of the monetary contributions, the family court erred in awarding Wife 35 per cent of the marital estate.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s apportionment of the marital estate.[9]
Here, the family court in this case recited that it considered all the statutory factors regarding equitable apportionment found.Â  Although Husband made the most of the monetary contributions to the marital estate, Wife made significant indirect contributions, assisting with both the Clover renovation and construction of the garage apartment and doing yard work and painting.Â  Furthermore, the marriage was fairly long in duration, Wife now has the lesser earning capacity, and Husbandâ€™s actions directly contributed to the breakup of the marriage.Â  We find no abuse of discretion. 
3.Â  Husbandâ€™s next contention is that the family court should not have awarded Wife alimony of $250.00 per month.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.[10]  
The marriage lasted 18 years, a relatively long duration. Wife is now disabled and in her sixties.Â  Additionally, Wife suffered emotionally due to the breakup of the marriage.Â  
Although Husband is also disabled, his income is higher than hers.Â  Both parties are on fixed incomes.Â  Wifeâ€™s education and prior work experience are limited; therefore, training is unlikely to improve her earning potential.Â  In addition, Husband received 65 per cent of the marital estate in the equitable distribution.
Although the standard of living during the marriage was in dispute, Wife testified that they had â€œa good life standard of livingâ€ without financial problems, and Husband admitted they enjoyed money from the sale of his investments.Â  
Considering the foregoing, we hold the award of alimony to Wife in the amount of $250.00 per month was within the family courtâ€™s discretion.
4.Â  We reject Husbandâ€™s argument that the family court erred in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees she incurred to defend the divorce action he filed in Tennessee.
The family court has no jurisdiction to award attorneyâ€™s fees for actions brought in another court.[11]Â  Nevertheless, under South Carolina Code section 20-3-130(H), the family court has the authority to â€œorder one party to pay a reasonable amount to the other for attorney fees, expert fees, investigation fees, costs, and suit money incurred in maintaining an action for divorce from the bonds of matrimony.â€[12]
In our view, the family court acted properly in requiring Husband to reimburse Wife for attorneyâ€™s fees she incurred as a result the Tennessee lawsuit.Â  Here, the fees in dispute were awarded at the temporary hearing upon a finding by the family court that Husbandâ€™s actions â€œnecessitated the Plaintiff having to hire an attorney in Tennessee to get an action dismissed.â€Â  After Wife filed for divorce in South Carolina, Husband evaded service, went to Tennessee, where he apparently had no prior contacts, and attempted to commence a separate divorce action there by making questionable assertions that he was a â€œbona fide resident of Jefferson County, Tennessee,â€ and that â€œthe acts complained of were committed while Husband was a resident of Jefferson County, Tennessee.â€Â  Given the possibility that Wifeâ€™s South Carolina action could have been halted because an action between the parties regarding the same matters was pending in another court,[13] we hold the reimbursement to Wife of the fees she incurred to have this other action dismissed was properly granted as a â€œcostâ€ necessarily incurred in maintaining the present case.
5.Â  Husband also challenges the amount of the attorneyâ€™s fees award.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.[14]Â  The family court awarded $4,500.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wifeâ€™s attorney submitted an affidavit of fees and costs of $3,230.34, including 22.30 hours of work and costs in the amount of $898.34.Â  Wife conceded that this amount also includes charges incurred at the temporary hearing, in which Wife was awarded attorneyâ€™s fees of $500.00; however, Husband acknowledged he never paid the fees awarded in the temporary hearing.Â  The attorneyâ€™s fees awarded for the hiring and communications with the Tennessee attorney totaled $660.00.Â  In addition, trial time was not included in Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fee affidavit.Â  The family court expressly recited each of the required factors in the appealed order[15] and emphasized Wifeâ€™s success in receiving alimony as well as an equitable interest in the marital property.Â  Under these circumstances, we affirm the family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees. 
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  See Bailey v. Bailey, 330 S.C. 326, 330, 498 S.E.2d 891, 893 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding that the family court had no jurisdiction to apportion property excluded by a post-marital agreement); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(4) (Supp. 2004) (providing that property excluded by written contract, including an antenuptial agreement, is non-marital property).
[3]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(4).Â Â Â  
[4]Â  Id.
[5]Â  See Pappas v. Pappas, 300 S.C. 62, 66, 386 S.E.2d 301, 304 (Ct. App. 1989) (â€œTransmutation is . . . a matter of intent to be determined from the facts of each case.â€).
[6]Â  See Bryan v. Bryan, 296 S.C. 305, 308, 372 S.E.2d 116, 118 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œProperty, nonmarital at the time of its acquisition, may be transmuted into marital property (1) if it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable; (2) if it is titled jointly; or (3) if it is used in support of the marriage.â€).
[7]Â  See Pool v. Pool, 321 S.C. 84, 89, 467 S.E.2d 753, 757 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating contributions during the marriage to an IRA constitute marital property), affâ€™d as modified on other grounds, 329 S.C. 324, 494 S.E.2d 820 (1998). 
[8]Â  Husband also argues on appeal that â€œ[t]he camper had apparently depreciated almost fifty percentâ€; however, he offered no record citation to support this assertion and the family court did not make any ruling in the appealed order on depreciation.
[9]Â  See Roberson v. Roberson, 359 S.C. 384, 389, 597 S.E.2d 840, 842 (Ct. App. 2004) (stating the family court has discretion to decide what weight to assign the various equitable apportionment factors); Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 23, 553 S.E.2d 251, 255 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating the family courtâ€™s apportionment will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion); Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988) (stating that, â€œ[o]n review, this Court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionmentâ€).
[10] See Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002) (noting an alimony award will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion).
[11] See Burns v. Burns, 323 S.C. 45, 50, 448 S.E.2d 571, 573 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œThe award of attorneyâ€™s fees by the family court is limited to those fees incurred in actions brought in the family court.â€); Collins v. Collins, 239 S.C. 170, 178, 122 S.E.2d 1, 4 (1961) (holding that a court has no jurisdiction to award attorneyâ€™s fees incurred in related actions, including divorce actions commenced in other counties that were dismissed for lack of jurisdiction).Â  
[12] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(H) (Supp. 2004).
[13] See Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP (providing as a ground for judgment on the pleadings the defense that â€œanother action is pending between the same parties for the same claimâ€).
[14] See Bowen v. Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 563, 490 S.E.2d 271, 272 (Ct. App. 1997) (stating an award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the sound discretion of the family court).
[15] See Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991) (enumerating the factors that the family court should consider in determining reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Edna M. Evans,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
         Willie Anderson (deceased),
        Rosa Cureton  (deceased), Matilda JamesÂ  (deceased), Brown AndersonÂ  (deceased),Â Fred AndersonÂ  (deceased), Alvin AndersonÂ  (deceased),
        Lenzy AndersonÂ  (deceased), Curtis AndersonÂ  (deceased), Polly KayÂ  (deceased), Henry 
        Anderson, Jr., (deceased), Carrie AndersonÂ  (deceased), Lorene OsborneÂ  (deceased),
        Willie Anderson, Jr., Leonard S. Anderson, Ronald B. Anderson, Willie
        Cureton  (deceased), Rita Cureton McCorkleÂ  (deceased), Peggy McCorkle Lewis, Dollie
        McCorkle Sims, Brenda McCorkle Thomas, Rita McCorkle Reid, Gloria McCorkle Smith, Leroy
        James, Eddie R. Armstrong, William B. James, Henry Brown Anderson, James
        Anderson, Alma Lee Jones, Barbara "Jean" Anderson, Paul D. Anderson,
        Elizabeth Johnson, Hattie V. Harry, Titus Anderson, Gwendolyn Illena AndersonÂ  (deceased),
        Bernice CunninghamÂ  (deceased), Mary E. BrownÂ  (deceased), Timothy AndersonÂ  (deceased),
        Mildred Anderson, Eugene Cunningham, David Henry
        Cunningham, Paul Michael Cunningham, Irma Lee Cunningham, James Edward 
        Cunningham, Sandra Walker, Eddie Frank Cunningham, Alma
        Illena Cunningham, Gwendolyn Cherry, Bernettie Benton, Gaynell Buttram, aka Gaynell Foust,
        Maurice Buttram  (deceased), Edwin Lee Buttram, Patrick Buttram, Jimmy Louis
        Buttram, Gary Alex Buttram, Esther LaVern CarterÂ 
        (deceased), Gregory Carter, Mark Christopher Buttram
        (deceased), Sharon Buttram, aka Sharon May, Sheila Buttram, aka Sheila Ruth Davis, Randy Cleotha Miller, aka Randy
        Buttram, Samuel Anderson, James AndersonÂ  (deceased), Jamerza Yip, Philistine Jones,
        Ronald Anderson, Patricia L. Anderson Hatch, Carolyn Rouse,Mattie L. RouseÂ  (deceased), Mona V. Simms, Alvah Leroy
        Martin, Jr., Moffett Martin (deceased), Dorothy M. Martin (deceased), Henry W. Anderson,
        Sr., Carrie H. Johnson, Evelyn A. Grimes, Doris Jeanette Anderson Middlebrook
        (deceased), Robert H. Middlebrook, Sr.,Â  (deceased), Robert H. Middlebrook, Jr.,
        Garret Lavoid Middlebrook, Edwin E. Middlebrook, Krystal P. Middlebrook Meade, El Juan
        Middlebrook, James R. Anderson, Charles Anderson, Michael Anderson, Brian Anderson,
        Angela Anderson,  Audrey Anderson, James Harold Anderson (deceased), Carrie Harling, aka
        Carrie Daisy Kay, Rachel Anderson, Inez Anderson, Karen Renee Osborne, and Donna
        Bradley and also all other persons who may be entitled to claim under or through (named the
        deceased) Defendants, or any of the above-named Defendants who
        may be deceased, and also other persons unknown claiming any right, title, estate, interest in, or
        lien upon the real estate described in the Complaint herein, any unknown adult Defendants beingdesignated as a class John Doe,
        and any unknown Defendants under any disability or in the military service of the United
        States of America being designated as a class Richard
        Roe,         Defendants,Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Of whom Edwin E. Middlebrook is the,Â        
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-in-equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-295
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 25, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Daniel L. Draisen, of Anderson, for Appellant.
George P. Sullivan and David J. Brousseau, all of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:  Edwin E. Middlebrook appeals from an order by a master-in-equity approving a sales contract for real property owned by tenants in common, each of whom received his or her ownership interest in the property through inheritance.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Henry Anderson died intestate in 1945 leaving approximately thirty-three acres of real property located in Anderson County, South Carolina.Â  The real property passed by intestate succession to Henryâ€™s heirs as tenants in common.Â  
Henry was survived by his wife, Carrie Anderson, eight children, one grandchild of a predeceased daughter, and two grandchildren of a predeceased son.Â  Carrie died in 1971.Â  After Carrieâ€™s death, Alvin Anderson, a son of Henry, petitioned for and received letters of administration for Henryâ€™s estate.Â  Publication for a final settlement of the estate was accomplished in 1983 and 1984, but a final settlement was never actually achieved.Â  In 1989, Alvin died, and Willie Anderson, another son of Henry, was named personal representative.Â  When Willie died in 1993, the estate was still not finally settled and no substitute personal representative was ever named.Â  
Since the death of Carrie, the eight children have died, each leaving multiple heirs.Â  In fact, the number of co-tenants of the thirty-three acres, Henryâ€™s sole asset at death, has grown to a total of sixty-nine.Â  In the time since Willieâ€™s death, Edna Evans, a granddaughter of Henry and one of a handful of relatives still living in Anderson, looked after the property, and has coordinated the paying of taxes on it.Â  She did this by calling the oldest relative from each part of the family and asking him or her to pay a portion of the taxes.Â  According to Evans, some would not pay and she would make up any shortfall.Â  In 1997, Evans had the timber cut on the property and used the timber funds to pay the property taxes.Â  At the date of the hearing, only $310 remained from the timber funds, and the expected taxes were in excess of $1,000.Â  
Evans sought court approval to sell the property to third parties whom she contracted with in 1997.Â  The sale was specifically conditioned on court approval.Â  Evans filed a complaint asking the court to determine the â€œtrue owners as tenants in commonâ€ of the property and to order the sale of the property according to the contract for sale.Â  
Edwin Middlebrook, one of the co-tenants, challenged the request for court approval of the sale of the property.Â  Middlebrookâ€™s answer asked the court to determine the identity of the co-tenants and the interests of each, and requested the property first be offered to the tenants in common at private auction before approval of the contract for sale.Â  At trial, all parties stipulated to the determination of heirs as alleged in Evansâ€™s complaint.Â  Middlebrook admitted he learned of the property in approximately 2001 when he received a letter from Evans discussing the sale of the property.Â  At trial, Middlebrook offered to pay $60,000 for the property in order to keep it in the family and stated he would be willing to pay more, suggesting he would match the highest price.Â  Middlebrook admitted $60,000 was a fair price for the property.Â  
The master-in-equity found the contract should be approved, and the property sold for $60,000 in accord with the contract between Evans and the third parties.Â  Additionally, the court ordered the proceeds divided according to the heirsâ€™ ownership interests in the property.Â  Middlebrook appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA partition action is an equitable action, heard by a judge alone and, as such, this Court on review may find facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Anderson v. Anderson,  299 S.C. 110, 113, 382 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1989).Â  See also Freeman v. Freeman, 323 S.C. 95, 97-98, 473 S.E.2d 467, 469-70 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding an action to quiet title and partition property, where father died intestate and there was no indication that property was probated, to be an action in equity).Â  However, we are not required to disregard the findings of the master.Â  Freeman, 323 S.C. at 98, 473 S.E.2d at 469.Â  â€œNor are we required to ignore the fact that the master, who saw and heard the witnesses, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility.â€Â  Id. at 98, 473 S.E.2d at 470.
LAW AND DISCUSSION
Middlebrook alleges three errors by the master-in-equity.Â  First, he argues the master did not have subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Second, he asserts the master erred in finding a sales contract when Evans did not first seek and receive an order from the probate court to sell the property.Â  Third, he argues the master erred by upholding the contract for sale with the third parties when an heir was willing to purchase the property for the same price. 
1.Â  Subject matter jurisdiction
Middlebrook argues section 62-1-302 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) controls and vests the probate court with exclusive original subject matter jurisdiction thereby rendering the master-in-equity without jurisdiction in this case.Â  We disagree.[1]  
Section 62-1-302 provides:

To the full extent permitted by the Constitution, and except as otherwise specifically provided, the probate court has exclusive original jurisdiction over all subject matter related to: (1) estates of decedents, including the contest of wills, construction of wills, and determination of heirs and successors of decedents and estates of protected persons . . . .

(Emphasis added.)Â  
In this case, the master was not asked to determine the heirs and successors of Henry Anderson.Â  In fact, all the parties stipulated to the determination of the heirs as alleged in Evansâ€™s complaint.Â  Rather, the master relied on the subject matter jurisdiction granted by section 15-61-50 of the South Carolina Code (1976).Â  This section states, â€œThe court of common pleas has jurisdiction in all cases of real and personal estates held in joint tenancy or in common to make partition in kind or by allotment . . . .â€Â  See also Eichor v. Eichor, 290 S.C. 484, 487, 351 S.E.2d 353, 354 (Ct. App. 1986). 
Therefore, we find the master had subject matter jurisdiction over the present case pursuant to section 15-61-50.Â  
2.Â  Failure to obtain an order of sale from the probate court 
Middlebrook argues the master-in-equity erred in upholding the contract between Evans and the third parties because Evans did not first obtain an order of sale from the probate court.Â  We disagree.Â  
Middlebrook argues certain sections of the probate code require an order of sale from the probate court before a sales contract for estate property can be entered.Â  He relies on sections 62-3-711, 62-3-911, and 62-3-1301 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004).Â  However, we find these sections are inapplicable to this case.Â  
Section 62-3-711 (b) provides, â€œExcept where the will of the decedent authorizes to the contrary, a personal representative may not sell real property of the estate except as authorized pursuant to the procedure described in Section 62-3-1301 et seq. . . . .â€Â  In this case, the actions complained of were not taken by the personal representative.Â  Additionally, Evans entered into the contract conditioned upon court approval, which was granted.Â  Thus, this section does not require an order of sale from the probate court prior to the sale of the property.
Section 62-3-911 provides the probate court the power to partition property either in kind or by sale.Â  It specifically states:Â  

When two or more heirs or devisees are entitled to distribution of undivided interests in any personal or real property of the estate, the personal representative or one or more of the heirs or devisees may petition the court prior to the closing of the estate, to make partition. After notice to the interested heirs or devisees, the court shall partition the property in kind if it can be fairly and equitably partitioned in kind. If not subject to fair and equitable partition in kind, the court shall direct the personal representative to sell the property and distribute the proceeds.


  Embracing Middlebrookâ€™s position would require us to find this provision negates the power of the circuit court to hear cases involving partition of real property in an estate.Â  See S.C. Code Â§ 15-61-50 (1976).Â  However, â€œrepeal by implication is disfavored, and is found only when two statutes are incapable of any reasonable reconcilement.â€Â  See, e.g., Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors Div. of Unidynamics Corp., 319 S.C. 556, 558, 462 S.E.2d 858, 859 (1995).Â  Accordingly, we interpret section 62-3-911 as providing the probate court with tools necessary to effectively handle an estate, not granting it the exclusive ability to partition property held by co-tenants who received the property through an estate.Â  Therefore, we find this section does not require an order of sale from the probate court.
Finally, Middlebrook argues section 62-3-1301 prevents the master from upholding the sale of the property because it states: â€œThe provisions of this Part are herby declared to be the only procedure for the sale of lands by the court, except where the will of the decedent authorizes to the contrary.â€Â Â  First, this section concerns powers of the probate court.Â  Because we found the master properly has jurisdiction to partition the property, this section is inapplicable.Â  Additionally, the heading just above section 62-3-1301 explains that it provides a mechanism to allow for the â€œ[s]ale of real estate by probate court to pay debts.â€Â  See Lindsay v. Southern Farm Bureau Cas. Ins. Co.,  258 S.C. 272, 277, 188 S.E.2d 374, 376 (1972) (allowing reference to the title of an act to determine legislative intent).Â  Preservation of the property to pay estate debts is not an issue in this case.Â  Henry Anderson died in 1945 and based on articles of publication run in area newspapers in 1971, 1983, and 1984, it does not appear his estate has any outstanding debts.
Because the sections Middlebrook seeks to rely on are inapplicable, we find the master did not err by upholding the validity of the sales contract.
3.     Â Sale of the property to a third party rather than an heir 
Middlebrook argues the master erred in upholding a contract with the third parties when an heir was willing to purchase the property for the price offered by the third parties.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[A] court of equity may allocate a portion of the property under partition to one or more heirs while disposing of the remainder by sale.Â  Nevertheless, the division must be fair to all of the co-tenants.â€Â  Pinckney v. Atkins, 317 S.C. 340, 345, 454 S.E.2d 339, 342 (Ct. App. 1995) (citations omitted).Â  
Section 15-61-50 specifies: 

The court of common pleas has jurisdiction in all cases of real and personal estates held in joint tenancy or in common to make partition in kind or by allotment to one or more of the parties upon their accounting to the other parties in interest for their respective shares or, in case partition in kind or by allotment cannot be fairly and impartially made and without injury to any of the parties in interest, by the sale of the property and the division of the proceeds according to the rights of the parties.

(Emphasis added.)Â  This section does not specify a sale must be public or that property must first be offered to the heirs.Â  In Pruitt v. Pruitt, 298 S.C. 411, 414, 380 S.E.2d 862, 864 (Ct. App. 1989), we stated that â€œthe disparate testimony as to the value of the subject property requires partition by public sale, which will afford each party an opportunity to back her own judgment of value by bidding for the interest of the other.â€Â  In this case, Middlebrook agreed that $60,000 was a fair price for the property.Â  Additionally, the price was supported by the testimony of two certified real estate appraisers.Â  
Middlebrook apparently is motivated by a desire to keep the property in the family.Â  However, he had ample opportunity to act upon this desire prior to the hearing.Â  Moreover, he never presented a firm offer beyond promising the contract price and â€œmore, depending on what the price is.â€Â  Accordingly, we find the master did not err in upholding the sales contract with the third parties.Â Â  
For the reasons discussed above, the order of the master-in-equity is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We recognize Middlebrookâ€™s claim that the master lacked subject matter jurisdiction can be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  See, e.g., Simmons v. Bellamy, 349 S.C. 473, 476, 562 S.E.2d 687, 689 (Ct. App. 2002).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Brooke A. Jewell,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-296
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 25, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
William J. LaLima, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia;Â  andÂ  Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brooke Jewell appeals his guilty pleas to the charges of first-degree burglary and first-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  The trial judge sentenced Jewell to fifteen years imprisonment for first-degree burglary and twenty-one years imprisonment for first-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  The sentences were to be served concurrently. 
Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), counsel for Jewell attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating he had reviewed the record and concluded Jewellâ€™s appeal is without legal merit sufficient to warrant a new trial.Â  Jewell filed a separate pro se response.
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Anders and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED.[1]
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Shamrock Entertainment Corp., Inc.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The Beach Market, L.L.C. and Lara Development Company, Inc.,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-297
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed April 26, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert V. Mathison, Jr., of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
R. Nicholas Felix and Terry A. Finger, both of Hilton Head Island, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Shamrock Entertainment Corp., Inc., appeals from the decision of the trial court finding The Beach Market, L.L.C., had the right to place restrictions on Shamrockâ€™s use of common areas in the shopping center owned by Beach Market and in which Shamrock was a tenant.Â  Additionally, Shamrock appeals the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Beach Market and Lara Development Company, Inc., the denial of its injunction prohibiting the restrictions, and the finding it breached the lease.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Shamrock operates Hincheyâ€™s Chicago Bar and Grill, and has been the tenant under a commercial lease in a shopping center in Hilton Head since 1996.Â  Lara Development was the original landlord.Â  Lara Development allowed Shamrock to purchase outdoor furniture and to operate a seating area on the concrete plaza adjoining the buildings comprising the shopping center.Â  Shamrock served food and beverages, including alcoholic beverages, to patrons seated in the plaza.
Lara Development sold the shopping center to Beach Market, L.L.C. in 1999.Â  In the spring of 2000, Bruce Kimball, a fifty-percent owner of Beach Market, became concerned regarding excessive trash and noise occurring on the plaza late at night.Â  Beach Market sought to restrict the consumption of alcohol and other uses of the plaza.Â  Beach Market placed signs in the plaza specifically restricting the consumption of alcohol in the evenings.Â  Subsequently, Beach Market propagated and disseminated rules and regulations related to the use of the plaza as well as the sale of food and beverages.Â  
In July 2000, Beach Market applied in magistrateâ€™s court for the ejectment of Shamrock, alleging Shamrock was in default of the lease.Â  Shamrock instituted this declaratory judgment action, claiming the lease allowed the use of the plaza, or in the alternative the lease was modified to allow the use of the plaza.Â  Shamrock sought a temporary restraining order and injunction prohibiting the enforcement of Beach Marketâ€™s rules.Â  
After the magistrateâ€™s court action was dismissed, Beach Market answered and asserted there was no provision in the lease allowing the use of the plaza.Â  It sought to eject Shamrock because of the unauthorized use of the plaza. Â Lara Development also answered, denying Shamrockâ€™s allegations.Â  In reply to Beach Marketâ€™s counterclaim for breach of the lease, Shamrock asserted that even if its right to use the plaza was not included in the lease, Beach Market waived its right to prohibit or restrict the use of the plaza.Â Â  
Lara Development was granted an involuntary non-suit as to any claims alleged by Shamrock.Â  The trial court denied Shamrockâ€™s request for an injunction and denied Beach Marketâ€™s request for an eviction.Â  The court found the lease did not allow the use of the plaza, either originally or through a modification.Â  The court held Beach Market retained the right to place reasonable restrictions on the use of the plaza and had not waived that right.Â  It concluded Beach Marketâ€™s prohibition of alcohol consumption on the Plaza after 11:00 p.m. was reasonable.Â  Finally, the court awarded Beach Market and Lara Development attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  After the denial of Shamrockâ€™s motion for reconsideration, this appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  This is ultimately an action to determine the partiesâ€™ rights under the lease.Â  Therefore, the action is one at law.Â  See eg., Pruitt v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 343 S.C. 335, 339, 540 S.E.2d 843, 845 (2001) (stating an action to construe a contract is an action at law); Skull Creek Club Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Cook and Book, Inc., 313 S.C. 283, 286-87, 437 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Additionally, an action for an ejectment is an action at law.Â  Skull Creek, 313 S.C. at 286, 437 S.E.2d at 165.Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Terms of Lease
Shamrock contends the lease provides for its use of the plaza to serve food and beverages.Â  Additionally, Shamrock maintains the lease was ambiguous and should be read to include the use of the plaza.Â  We disagree.
In construing a contract, the primary objective is to ascertain and give effect to the intention of the parties as determined by the contractâ€™s language.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â  If its language is plain, unambiguous, and capable of only one reasonable interpretation, that language alone determines the instrumentâ€™s force and effect.Â  Jordan v. Security Group, Inc., 311 S.C. 227, 230, 428 S.E.2d 705, 707 (1993).
The lease included the following relevant provisions.

1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Leased Premises.Â  Landlord hereby leases to Tenant . . . Units 101, 102, and 103-B, The Beach Market . . . [t]he Leased Premises are depicted on the attached plan of Beach Market.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Permitted Use of the Leased Premises.Â  Tenant shall use and occupy the Leased Premises for the operation of a full service restaurant, including the sale of beer, wine and alcoholic beverages, subject to the terms and conditions in this Lease, and for all such uses as may be customarily incidental to Tenantâ€™s business. . . . Tenant shall have the exclusive right to sell alcoholic beverages, excluding beer, wine and low-alcohol drinks for on-premises consumption at The Beach Market.Â  

At oral argument, Shamrockâ€™s counsel conceded that the definition of â€œLeased Premisesâ€ does not include the plaza.Â  However, it contends the second paragraph provides it authority to sell food and beverages for consumption on the plaza, as that is an activity that is â€œincidental to Tenantâ€™s business.â€Â  We disagree and find a proper reading of paragraph two expressly limits it to the â€œLeased Premises.â€Â  Nothing in this paragraph can be read to allow Shamrock the use of the plaza when the paragraph begins:Â  â€œTenant shall use and occupy the Leased Premisesâ€ and does not include the plaza.Â  Furthermore, the last sentence granting Shamrock the exclusive right to sell alcoholic beverages for â€œon-premisesâ€ consumption does not provide it with authority to utilize the plaza to conduct its business without being restricted by the propertyâ€™s owner.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly determined the lease did not grant Shamrock the right to use the plaza for the operation of its business.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Modification of Lease
Shamrock argues Lara Development modified the lease by allowing Shamrock to use the plaza to conduct business and by allowing Shamrock to provide outdoor furniture for use on the plaza.Â  We disagree and find there was no modification of the lease.
â€œIt is well established that â€˜[a] written contract may be modified by a subsequent agreement of the parties, provided the subsequent agreement contains all the requisites of a valid contract.â€™Â  The necessary elements of a contract are an offer, acceptance, and valuable consideration.â€Â 
Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 405-06, 581 S.E.2d 161, 166 (2003) (citation omitted).Â  In addition, 

[i]t is well settled in South Carolina that in order for there to be a binding contract between parties, there must be a mutual manifestation of assent to the terms.Â  Furthermore, the assent must be as to all of the terms of the contract.Â  Some terms are considered indispensable to a binding contract.Â  Among these are price, time and place.Â Â  

Edens v. Laurel Hill, Inc., 271 S.C. 360, 364, 247 S.E.2d 434, 436 (1978) (citations omitted).
â€œWhen the existence of a contract is questioned and the evidence either conflicts or gives rise to more than one inference, the issue of the contractâ€™s existence becomes a question for the finder of fact.â€Â  Sherman v. W&B Enterprises, 357 S.C. 243, 250, 592 S.E.2d 307, 310 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
We find the evidence is susceptible to more than one inference as to Lara Development and Shamrockâ€™s mutual assent to the terms of a modification.Â  The record supports the trial courtâ€™s finding that the parties did not intend a modification of the lease to grant Shamrock a leasehold interest in the plaza, which would allow Shamrock unlimited use of the plaza twenty-four hours a day.Â  While Lara Development may have consented to Shamrockâ€™s use of the plaza for food and beverage service during normal restaurant hours, it denied any modification of the lease.Â  Furthermore, there was no additional consideration provided for the right to use the plaza.Â  Shamrock contends the additional business brought in constituted consideration.Â  However, this is speculative at best and there is no indication in the record indicating there was additional business brought into the shopping center.Â  Shamrock did not pay for the right to use the plaza, nor did it offer anything of value to Lara Development.[1]Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding that there was no modification of the lease. 
III.Â Â Â  Estoppel and Waiver of Ownerâ€™s Rights
Shamrock argues the trial court erred in finding Lara Development and, subsequently, Beach Market did not waive their right to place restrictions on the use of the plaza.Â  It also contends Beach Market should be estopped from placing restrictions on the use of the plaza.Â  We find Beach Market retained the right to place restrictions on the property it owned which was not leased to Shamrock. 
Waiver is a question of fact for the finder of fact.Â  Parker v. Parker, 313 S.C. 482, 487, 443 S.E.2d 384, 391 (1994). Waiver is a voluntary and intentional abandonment or relinquishment of a known right.Â  Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas Horiz. Prop.Â  Regime, 307 S.C. 339, 344, 415 S.E.2d 384, 388 (1992).Â  A party is not necessarily barred from enforcing a right where a previous deviation from its rights has been allowed.Â  Rabon v. Mali, 289 S.C. 37, 40, 344 S.E.2d 608, 610 (1986).Â  A partyâ€™s waiver of the right to object to a minor violation of its rights does not result in waiver of the right to object to a subsequent and more substantial violation.Â  Gibbs v. Kimbrell, 311 S.C. 261, 268, 428 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
Estoppel applies when a party, relying upon what another has said or done, changes its position to its detriment.Â  Id.Â  In addition, estoppel applies â€œwhen a party observes another dealing with his property in a manner inconsistent with his rights and makes no objection while the other changes his position in reliance on the partyâ€™s silence; the partyâ€™s silence is acquiescence that estops him from later seeking relief.â€Â 
Id.Â  
â€œA tenant has been defined to be one who occupies the lands or premises of another in subordination to that otherâ€™s title, and with his assent, express or implied.â€Â  Columbia Ry., Gas & Elec. Co. v. Jones, 119 S.C. 480, 490112 S.E. 267, 271 (1922).Â  â€œProperty in a thing consists not merely in its ownership and possession, but in the unrestricted right of use, enjoyment, and disposal.â€Â  Gasque v. Town of Conway, 194 S.C. 15, 8 S.E.2d 871, 873 (1940), overruled on other grounds, McCall by Andrews v. Batson, 285 S.C. 243, 329 S.E.2d 741 (1985) (overruling cases that held the State could not be sued without its consent).Â  Property owners also possess the right to protect their property.Â  See State v. Thompson, 349 S.C. 346, 350, 563 S.E.2d 325, 327 (2002).Â  
Beach Market as the owner of the shopping center possesses the right to control those portions not leased to the tenants.Â  As the plaza was a common area, it was subject to the restrictions established by Beach Market.Â  By merely allowing Shamrock to utilize the plaza to serve food for a portion of its lease, Beach Market did not waive its right to place restrictions on that use if they become necessary. Â The trial court found Beach Market did not waive its right to limit the use of the plaza.Â  There was no evidence in the record to show Beach Market intentionally abandoned its right to protect its property or to forego placing reasonable restrictions on the propertyâ€™s use.Â  Additionally, Beach Market placed the restrictions in an effort to reduce the litter and other damage being done to the property by the number of people utilizing the plaza.Â  Accordingly, we find Beach Market retained the right to use or restrict the use of the plaza.
In addition, we find Beach Market is not estopped from limiting Shamrockâ€™s use of the plaza.[2]Â  As evidence of its detrimental reliance for its estoppel defense, Shamrock relies on its acquisition of outdoor furniture for the purpose of serving food and alcoholic beverages to persons on the plaza.Â  However, at the most, we find the incurring of this expense would afford it only a right to continue serving food and alcohol on the plaza during normal restaurant hours, a practice Beach Market is not seeking to restrict.Â  It does not grant Shamrock unlimited use of plaza for patrons milling about consuming alcohol into the morning hours.Â  
Accordingly, we find the trial court properly determined Beach Market, as the owner of the plaza, retained and did not waive the right to place restrictions on the plazaâ€™s use.
IV.Â Â Â  Lara Development
Shamrock contends the trial court erred in finding it failed to assert a claim upon which relief may be granted against Lara Development.Â  Shamrock asserts it was error to grant Lara Developmentâ€™s motion for an involuntary dismissal.Â  We disagree.
Pursuant to Rule 41(b), SCRCP:Â  â€œAfter the plaintiff in an action tried by the court without a jury has completed the presentation of his evidence, the defendant . . .Â  may move for a dismissal on the ground that upon the facts and the law the plaintiff has shown no right to relief.â€Â  Rule 41(b) allows the judge as fact finder to weigh the evidence, determine the facts, and render judgment against the plaintiff if justified at this stage of the trial.Â  Johnson v. J.P. Stevens & Co., 308 S.C. 116, 118, 417 S.E.2d 527, 529 (1992).Â  
Shamrockâ€™s complaint sought a declaratory judgment requesting the court find the restrictions placed by Beach Market after it took possession of the shopping center were invalid.Â  Additionally, Shamrock alleged it was a breach of its lease by Beach Market to place the restrictions on the plazaâ€™s use and to otherwise injure its business.Â  It sought an injunction prohibiting enforcement of the restrictions.Â  None of these claims assert any action by Lara Development that injured Shamrock, nor do the claims request any relief against Lara Development.Â  Accordingly, the dismissal of the claims against Lara is affirmed.Â  
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Shamrockâ€™s Breach of Lease
Shamrock asserts the trial court erred in finding it breached the lease by utilizing the plaza and allowing excess littering and other damage to occur.Â  Although the trial court found a breach of the lease, it refused to order eviction.Â  Accordingly, we find no reversible error in the trial courtâ€™s finding of a breach.Â  See McCall v. Finley, 294 S.C. 1, 4, 362 S.E.2d 26, 28 (Ct. App. 1987) (stating that this court has long recognized that â€œwhatever doesnâ€™t make any difference, doesnâ€™t matterâ€).
VI.Â Â Â  Damages
Shamrock asserts there was no evidence of damages and the master erred in finding Shamrock caused Beach Market damages through its use of the plaza.Â  We disagree.
Beach Market provided evidence that it had to expend money to clean the area of the plaza, including the removal of excessive litter left by patrons of Shamrock.Â  While there may be no permanent damage to the property, there was evidence of damage to the landscaping, bathrooms, and parking area due to the late night use of the property.Â  Accordingly, we find evidence to support the findings of the master regarding damages created by Shamrockâ€™s use of the plaza.
VII.Â Â  Injunction
Shamrock contends the trial court erred in failing to award an injunction.Â  We disagree.
An injunction is a drastic remedy and should be cautiously applied only when legal rights are unlawfully invaded or legal duties are willfully or wantonly neglected.Â  LeFurgy v. Long Cove Club Owners Assâ€™n, Inc., 313 S.C. 555, 558, 443 S.E.2d 577, 578 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  In this case, we have found no legal right of Shamrock being abridged by Beach Market.Â  Accordingly, as we find Beach Market had the right to place the restrictions on the use of the plaza, we conclude the trial court properly denied Shamrockâ€™s request for an injunction.
VIII.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Shamrock maintains the court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Lara Development and Beach Market.Â  The lease provided for the payment of attorneyâ€™s fees to the prevailing party in a dispute regarding the lease.Â  Shamrockâ€™s main contention is that the decision of the trial court should be reversed making Shamrock the prevailing party.Â  As we affirm the decision of the trial court, we find no error in its award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Lara Development and Beach Market under the terms of the lease.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL,JJ., concur.Â  

[1] Shamrock contends consideration for the modification existed in the detriment it incurred in purchasing furniture for the Plaza.Â  See Shayne of Miami v. Greybow, Inc., 232 S.C. 161, 167, 101 S.E.2d 486, 489 (1957) (stating consideration may consist of any benefit to the promisor or in a loss or detriment to the promisee). Â Â Our decision to affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding of no modification is based solely on the partiesâ€™ intent as to a modification.Â  We mention the lack of formal consideration only as evidence the partiesâ€™ did not intend a modification of the lease to grant Shamrock a leasehold interest in the plaza.Â  
[2] Our conclusion remains the same applying either an equitable or law standard of review.Â  See Maher v. Tietex Corp., 331 S.C. 371, 381 n.1,Â  500 S.E.2d 204, 209 n.1 (Ct.App.1998) (noting claim of equitable estoppel would fail under either a law or equity standard of review).
