title: Rosenblum v. Carbone
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Barry Rosenblum, Appellant/Respondent,
v.
Michael and Gale Carbone, and Doug Muraglia, Nick Rini and Fedfirst Mortgage Corporation and Laurich &
Deeb, P.A., as Escrow Agent, and Suntrust Mortgage Corporation, Defendants, of whom, Nick
Rini, Suntrust Mortgage Corporation and Doug Muraglia, are, Respondents/Appellants
and
Michael and Gale Carbone, and FedFirst Mortgage Corporation, are,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-298
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed April 26, 2005
Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled on June 22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Capers G. Barr, III, of Charleston, and Gregory Milam Alford, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant-Respondent.
Gale Carbone, Pro Se, of South Belmar, and Ralph E. Tupper, of Beaufort, for Respondents.
Charles H. Gibbs, Jr., of Charleston, and Thomas Holloway, of Beaufort, for Respondent-Appellants.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Â  This is an appeal from the final order of the trial court:Â  (1) entering judgment against Doug Muraglia and Michael and Gayle[1] Carbone for civil conspiracy; (2) refusing to subordinate the interests in real property of Nick Rini and Suntrust Mortgage to a mortgage held by Rosenblum; and (3) denying Rosenblumâ€™s foreclosure of the mortgage.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Rosenblum, Michael Carbone (Carbone), and Muraglia are all residents of New Jersey.Â  Rosenblum testified that after liquidating a family business, he placed the assets in several law firm trust accounts, including a firm for which both Carbone and Muraglia worked.Â  When Rosenblum requested Carbone return the money, Carbone initially stalled.Â  He subsequently admitted that he and Muraglia had invested the money in different things and had lost the money.Â  In order to repay Rosenblum, Carbone executed in favor of Rosenblum a mortgage note for $200,000.Â  He secured the debt with a mortgage on property in Hilton Head he and Gayle had purchased in 1997.Â  Although Gayleâ€™s signature appears on the mortgage dated March 20, 2000, which purports to convey a mortgage interest on the entire property, Gayle in fact had conveyed her half interest in the property to Muraglia in 1998.[2] Â Â In addition, Michael Carbone signed a Demand Promissory Note in the amount of $220,300 to Rosenblum.Â  Rosenblumâ€™s counsel acknowledged at oral argument that both notes constituted the same obligation.Â  
Four days after executing the notes and mortgage in favor of Rosenblum, Carbone deeded his one-half interest in the property to Muraglia.Â  Muraglia then filed and recorded his deed in the Office of the Register of Deeds for Beaufort County on March 29, 2000.Â  Rosenblum did not record his mortgage until March 31, 2000.Â  
On October 6, 2000, Rosenblum brought suit against Carbone in New Jersey to collect on the Demand Promissory Note.Â  He maintained in the action that the note was secured by the mortgage on the Hilton Head property.Â  On April 4, 2001, Carbone declared bankruptcy.Â  In his petition to the bankruptcy court, Carbone listed the $220,300 note as an unsecured debt owed to Rosenblum.Â  The bankruptcy court discharged the note.Â  As a result, on September 28, 2001, the New Jersey court dismissed Rosenblumâ€™s action with prejudice, finding the note was discharged.Â  
In the meantime, Rosenblum initiated the current action.Â  On February 27, 2001, Rosenblum filed a lis pendens in Beaufort County on the Hilton Head Property.Â  Twenty-one days later, after the lis pendens expired, Rosenblum filed the original complaint in this action, seeking to set aside the conveyance from Carbone to Muraglia.Â  The complaint alleged Carbone transferred the property to Muraglia in an attempt to defraud Rosenblum.Â  
On April 20, 2001, Muraglia entered into a contract to sell the Hilton Head property to Rini.Â  On November 19, 2001, the attorney handling the closing for both Muraglia and Rini sent a fax request to Rosenblumâ€™s attorney to determine the status of the lis pendens and to have it removed from the property.Â  Even though the lis pendens was not removed, Muraglia sold the property to Rini on November 26, 2001.Â  
Rosenblum amended his complaint to add as parties Rini and FedFirst, which had Riniâ€™s mortgage on the property.Â  In his second amended complaint, Rosenblum alleged the Carbones and Muraglia engaged in a civil conspiracy and sought the additional relief of foreclosure on the mortgage to the Hilton Head property, equitable subordination, and an injunction as to the proceeds of the sale to Rini.Â  
The trial court found the Carbones and Muraglia engaged in a civil conspiracy â€œto cheat [Rosenblum] from his money.â€Â  It awarded as damages the amount that would have been due under the note, $269,500.00.Â  However, the trial court concluded Rini was an innocent purchaser for value of the property and refused to subordinate FedFirstâ€™s mortgage or Riniâ€™s ownership to the interest of Rosenblum.Â  Finally, the referee found the mortgage held by Rosenblum was â€œnot entitled to be recorded . . . .â€Â  Rosenblum filed a motion to reconsider, which was denied.Â  Rosenblum, Muraglia, and Rini appealed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether the action is one at law or in equity is determined by the nature of the pleadings and the character of the relief sought.Â  In re Estate of Holden, 343 S.C. 267, 278, 539 S.E.2d 703, 709 (2000).Â  The appellate court will apply the appropriate standard of review for a particular issue in a case that contains both legal and equitable issues.Â  Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 416, 503 S.E.2d 191, 200 (Ct. App. 1998).Â Â  
An action for civil conspiracy is an action at law; the trial judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld on appeal unless they are without evidentiary support.Â  Gynecology Clinic v. Cloer, 334 S.C. 555, 557, 514 S.E.2d 592, 592-93 (1999).Â  This case also involves Rosenblumâ€™s requests to foreclose his mortgage.Â  â€œAn action to foreclose a real estate mortgage is an action in equity.â€Â  BB & T of S.C. v. Kidwell, 350 S.C. 382, 387, 565 S.E.2d 316, 319 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  On appeal from an action in equity, this court may â€œfind facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Â A.Â Â Â Â  Personal and Subject Matter Jurisdiction
Muraglia asserts the trial court erred in denying his motion to dismiss due to lack of personal and subject matter jurisdiction.Â  As to the issue of personal jurisdiction, we find Muragliaâ€™s argument so conclusory as to be abandoned.Â  See Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œSouth Carolina law clearly states that short, conclusory statements made without supporting authority are deemed abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for review.â€).Â Â  
Although Muragliaâ€™s argument as to the trial courtâ€™s lack of subject matter jurisdiction is equally conclusory, we will address this argument as this court may address the issue of subject matter jurisdiction sua sponte.Â  See Lake v. Reeder Constr. Co., 330 S.C. 242, 248, 498 S.E.2d 650, 653 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œLack of subject matter jurisdiction can be raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on appeal, and can be raised sua sponte by the court.â€).Â  
Subject matter jurisdiction is the courtâ€™s power to hear and determine a particular class of cases.Â  Whaley v. CSX Transp., 362 S.C. 456, ___, 609 S.E.2d 286, 295 (2005).Â  The trial court certainly had the power to hear and determine actions forÂ  subrogation and foreclosure of a mortgage and civil conspiracy.Â  Accordingly we find Muragliaâ€™s argument that the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction is meritless.Â  
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Res Judicata and Collateral Estoppel
Muraglia argues Rosenblumâ€™s claims are barred by the doctrines of res judicata and collateral estoppel.Â  He maintains Rosenblum raised the same issues or could have raised the issues in his New Jersey lawsuit.Â  We agree.[3]
Res judicata bars subsequent actions by the same parties when the claims arise out of the same transaction or occurrence that was the subject of a prior action between those parties.Â  Plum Creek Dev. Co., Inc. v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 34, 512 S.E.2d 106, 109 (1999).Â  Under the doctrine of res judicata, â€œ[a] litigant is barred from raising any issues which were adjudicated in the former suit and any issues which might have been raised in the former suit.â€Â  Id.Â  (quoting Hilton Head Ctr. of S.C., Inc. v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n of South Carolina, 294 S.C. 9, 11, 362 S.E.2d 176, 177 (1987)).Â  â€œTo establish res judicata, the defendant must prove the following three elements: Â (1) identity of the parties; (2) identity of the subject matter; and (3) adjudication of the issue in the former suit.â€Â 
Id.Â  
â€œUnder the doctrine of collateral estoppel, once a final judgment on the merits has been reached in a prior claim, the relitigation of those issues actually and necessarily litigated and determined in the first suit are precluded as to the parties and their privies in any subsequent action based upon a different claim.â€Â  Richburg v. Baughman, 290 S.C. 431, 434, 351 S.E.2d 164, 166 (1986).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A party may assert nonmutual collateral estoppel to preclude relitigation of a previously litigated issue unless the party sought to be precluded did not have a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issue in the first proceeding, or unless other circumstances justify providing the party an opportunity to relitigate the issue.Â  Wade v. Berkeley County, 330 S.C. 311, 317, 498 S.E.2d 684, 687 (Ct. App. 1998).
In the New Jersey action, Rosenblum sought to collect on the $220,300 Demand Promissory Note, which his counsel admitted was the same debt as the mortgage note.Â  In his complaint, he asserted that although he had accepted the mortgage to secure the note, â€œCarboneâ€™s actions rendered the Collateral worthless.â€Â  The New Jersey Superior Court dismissed Rosenblumâ€™s action with prejudice.Â  
Rosenblumâ€™s New Jersey action and South Carolina action both sought collection of the same debt.Â  The dismissal of Rosenblumâ€™s case with prejudice constitutes an adjudication on the merits.Â  See Nelson v. QHG of S.C., Inc., 354 S.C. 290, 311, 580 S.E.2d 171, 182 (Ct. App. 2003), affâ€™d in part and revâ€™d in part on other grounds by 362 S.C. 421, 608 S.E.2d 855 (2005), (â€œA case that is dismissed â€˜with prejudiceâ€™ indicates an adjudication on the merits and, pursuant to res judicata, prohibits subsequent litigation to the same extent as if the action had been tried to a final adjudication.â€).Â  As Rosenblum has already sought unsuccessfully to collect the debt in New Jersey, he is precluded from seeking collection of the same debt in South Carolina.Â  Thus, he had no right to foreclose the mortgage.Â  See 55 AmJur.2d Mortgages Â§ 359 (1996) (stating anything that operates to extinguish the debt necessarily operates to discharge the mortgage). 
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Civil Conspiracy
Muraglia asserts the trial court erred in finding Rosenblum proved he participated in a civil conspiracy and in awarding damages as a result.Â  We disagree.
A civil conspiracy consists of (1) a combination of two or more persons, (2) for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff, (3) which causes the plaintiff special damages.Â  Hammond v. Butler, Means, Evins & Brown, 300 S.C. 458, 463, 388 S.E.2d 796, 798 (1990).Â  â€œConspiracy may be inferred from the very nature of the acts done, the relationship of the parties, the interests of the alleged conspirators, and other circumstances.â€Â  Island Car Wash, Inc. v. Norris, 292 S.C. 595, 601, 358 S.E.2d 150, 153 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  â€œCivil conspiracy is an act which is by its very nature covert and clandestine and usually not susceptible of proof by direct evidence; concert of action, amounting to a conspiracy, may be shown by circumstantial as well as direct evidence.â€Â  Id.Â  
Rosenblum testified Carbone confessed that he and Muraglia had taken Rosenblumâ€™s money to invest it and had lost it.Â  Rosenblum also recounted how a few days after Carbone executed the mortgage, Muraglia informed Rosenblum that he had filed a mortgage[4] before Rosenblum and taunted him, â€œ[H]a, ha, ha, you ainâ€™t getting [the property].â€Â  The record demonstrates that although Carbone had executed the mortgage in favor of Rosenblum, he quickly conveyed his interest in the same property to his alleged co-conspirator, who immediately filed the deed to win a â€œrace to the courthouse.â€Â  Under our limited standard of review of this action at law, we find the record supports the trial courtâ€™s finding that a civil conspiracy existed.Â  
Muraglia asserts that Rosenblumâ€™s claim for civil conspiracy should fail because Rosenblum failed to prove any â€œspecial damagesâ€ as the remedy he sought was the same as he sought in his equitable claims.Â  We find no indication in the record that Muraglia raised this specific argument to the trial court.Â  Therefore, it is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
Muraglia also asserts that as at the most Rosenblum was ever entitled to is Carboneâ€™s interest in the property, the proper measure of damages would have been the equity value of that half interest, not the full amount of the extinguished promissory note executed by Carbone.Â  Muraglia failed to raise this argument to the trial court either at the hearing or in a post-trial motion when he learned of the trial courtâ€™s award of damages.Â  Accordingly, we find this argument not preserved.Â  See Godfrey v. Heller, 311 S.C. 516, 520, 429 S.E.2d 859, 862 (Ct.App.1993) (where an appellant learns for the first time when the appellant receives the order that the respondent would be granted certain relief, the appellant must move, pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment to preserve the issue).Â  Therefore, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s award of damages on Rosenblumâ€™s civil conspiracy claim.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.[5]
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] While the caption of the case lists her as â€œGaleâ€ Carbone, the documents in the record show her signing as â€œGayleâ€ Carbone.Â  For purposes of this opinion, she will be referred to as â€œGayle.â€
[2]  There were allegations that Gayle did not sign the mortgage herself.Â  
[3] During the trial, Muraglia and Rini moved to dismiss the action and sought a directed verdict on the grounds that the action was barred by res judicata, collateral estoppel, or judicial estoppel. Â The trial court took the motions under advisement but never explicitly ruled on the motions.Â  As Rini and Muraglia were the prevailing parties as to subrogation and foreclosure of the mortgage, they were not required to secure a ruling on these issues in order to preserve them for appeal.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 423, 526 S.E.2d 716, 725 (2000) (â€œ[W]hen the lower court rules in one partyâ€™s favor, it is not necessary for that party to return to the court and ask for a ruling on remaining issues and arguments in order to preserve those arguments for use in an appeal.).Â Â  However, as the trial court found against Mugaglia on Rosenblumâ€™s claim for civil conspiracy, it was incumbent upon Muraglia to file a Rule 59, SCRCP,Â  motion asking for a ruling on his defenses of res judicata and collateral estoppel, in order for this court to address these defenses as they apply to the claim of civil conspiracy. See id. at 421-22, 526 S.E.2d at 724 (noting different preservation rules apply to the losing party in the lower court and providing:Â  â€œIf the losing party has raised an issue in the lower court, but the court fails to rule upon it, the party must file a motion to alter or amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appellate review.â€).Â  As Muraglia failed to file a Rule 59, SCRCP motion seeking a ruling on these defenses, we may not address them in our consideration of the claim for civil conspiracy.Â Â Â Â Â  
[4] From the record, it appears Muraglia only received a deed, not a mortgage, from Carbone.Â  
[5] As we affirm the trial court for the above stated reasons, we need not address the partiesâ€™ remaining arguments.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kobe Carter,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-299
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed April 27, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David M. Collins, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott
Senior Assistant Attorney General Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Kobe Carter was convicted of trafficking in cocaine in the amount of 100 grams or more and possession of crack cocaine.Â  The trial judge sentenced Carter to twenty-five years on the trafficking charge and five years on the possession charge.Â  Carter appeals, arguing the trial judge erred in admitting narcotics and money obtained as a result of an illegal search and seizure.Â  We affirm1 pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 642, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001) (â€œIn most cases, â€˜[m]aking a motion in limine to exclude evidence at the beginning of trial does not preserve an issue for review because a motion in limine is not a final determination.Â  The moving party, therefore, must make a contemporaneous objection when the evidence is introduced.â€™â€) (citation omitted); State v. Smith, 337 S.C. 27, 32, 522 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1999) (â€œA pretrial ruling on the admissibility of evidence is preliminary and is subject to change based on developments at trial.Â  A ruling in limine is not final; unless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling procured, the issue is not preserved for review.â€) (citation omitted); State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 42, 479 S.E.2d 57, 60 (1996) (â€œA ruling in limine is not a final ruling on the admissibility of evidence.Â  Unless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling made, the issue is not preserved for review.â€) (citation omitted).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(1), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Shirley J. Griffin and Henry R. Griffin, and Jacquelyn G. Burke and Michael J. Burke,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
White Oak Properties, LLC, Eugene Grissom McDonald, III, a/k/a Gris McDonald, and Home Shop Realty Company,
Of whom
Home Shop Realty Company is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-301
Heard March 8, 2005 â€“ Filed April 27, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
W. Shell Suber, Jr. and Robert J. Thomas, both of Columbia, for Appellant. 
Clifford O. Koon, Paul D. de Holczer, and Mary Frances Gibson, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Home Shop Realty Company appeals from the trial judgeâ€™s denial of a directed verdict and award of attorneyâ€™s fees in favor of Shirley and Henry Griffin and Jacquelyn and Michael Burke on their breach of contract action.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In 2000, Eugene Grissom McDonald was employed as a real estate agent for Home Shop Realty, a real estate brokerage company.Â  McDonald was also the sole member of a limited liability company called White Oak Properties, LLC.Â  White Oak was formed for the purpose of purchasing, renovating, and reselling investment property.Â  In April of 2000, White Oak purchased real estate located at 4676 Crystal Drive in Columbia for $62,000.Â  White Oak, through McDonald, renovated the property and listed it for sale in October of 2000 for $128,000.Â  The multiple listing service for real estate named Home Shop Realty as the real estate listing office.Â  
During that same time, the Griffins became interested in purchasing investment property to be used as a residence by the Burkes, their daughter and son-in-law.Â  While house hunting, the Burkes saw the Crystal Drive property with a Home Shop Realty sign in the front yard listing McDonaldâ€™s number as the contact number.Â  The Burkes called the number, talked with McDonald, and were shown the property.Â  Based on the Burkesâ€™ representations, the Griffins decided to purchase the Crystal Drive property.Â Â Â  
On December 13, 2000, the Griffins entered into a contract for sale with White Oak, through McDonald, to purchase the Crystal Drive property for $122,000.Â  On December 28, 2000, the Griffins entered into an installment sales contract with White Oak for the same property.Â  From this sale, Home Shop Realty was paid $250 in commissions or administrative fees, and the Griffinsâ€™ real estate agent was paid $4,270 in commissions.Â  
When the Burkes moved into the Crystal Drive home, they discovered numerous problems with the residence, including a defective foundation.Â  The Griffins and Burkes sued McDonald, White Oak, and Home Shop alleging breach of the contract for sale, fraud, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, negligent misrepresentation, civil conspiracy, violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act, and piercing the corporate veil.Â  
At trial, Shirley Griffin and the Burkes all testified that they knew McDonald and White Oak were the owners and sellers of the Crystal Drive property.Â  McDonald signed the contracts for sale as the seller of the property on behalf of White Oak.Â  Neither the Burkes nor the Griffins alleged that McDonald was acting as an agent for Home Shop in signing the contract for sale or testified that he or she believed Home Shop was the owner and seller.
Home Shop moved for a directed verdict on the grounds that McDonald was the seller, and there was no evidence McDonald was acting as the agent of Home Shop.Â  The trial judge denied the motion.Â  The causes of action were submitted to the jury through a special verdict form.Â  The jury rejected all of the Burkesâ€™ and Griffinsâ€™ causes of action, except breach of contract.Â  Through the special verdict form, the jury found â€œDefendants breached the Contract for the purchase of the home on Crystal Drive,â€ and that â€œDefendants should take the home back and return the purchase money to the Plaintiffs.â€Â  The jury did not distinguish between any of the defendants and did not award any other damages.Â  
Through an â€œOrder Dealing with Post-trial Motions,â€ the trial judge granted the Griffinsâ€™ and Burkesâ€™ motion for attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $40,626.Â  Home Shop made a â€œMotion for an Interpretation of the Verdict or in the alternative Judgment For This Defendant Not Withstanding the Verdictâ€ on the grounds that it was not a party to the contract for sale.Â  The trial judge denied the motion, stating:

Home Shop presented evidence at trial and argued at the appropriate times that no agency relationship existed between Home Shop and the McDonald Defendants that would render Home Shop liable to a judgment in this case.Â  However, ample evidence was presented at trial that Home Shop allowed the McDonald Defendants to list and sell property through Home Shopâ€™s brokerage.Â  A Home Shop sign was placed on the subject property as an advertisement for sale.Â  Whit Suber, the owner and Broker at Home Shop, entered the premises on one or more occasions during the time the house was listed for sale according to the key box activity report which was entered into evidence.Â  Home Shop was also the listing Broker when the house was listed on the multiple listing service.Â Â  Suber denied that he ever personally showed the house to potential buyers.Â  However, the uncontradicted evidence of his accessing the multiple listing service key box and his failure to provide a plausible explanation for his entry other than â€œshowingâ€ the house, is sufficient to allow the jury to reasonably infer the existence of an agency relationship.Â  At the very least, the uncontradicted documentary and testimonial evidence of Home Shopâ€™s sign being on the property supports an inference of apparent authority.Â  

Finally, the judge denied all of White Oakâ€™s and McDonaldâ€™s motions.Â  The trial judge reiterated that judgment was entered against all defendants - McDonald, White Oak, and Home Shop.Â  Home Shop renewed its motions and argued that attorneyâ€™s fees should not be assessed against it because it was not a party to the contract.Â  These motions were also denied.Â  Home Shop appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Home Shop asserts the trial judge erred in denying its motion for a directed verdict on the breach of contract claim because there is no evidence that Home Shop was a party to the contract for sale or participated in the sale.Â  We agree.Â  
In reviewing a denial of a motion for directed verdict, this court must view all evidence and reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the opposing party.Â  Bultman v. Barber, 277 S.C. 5, 7, 281 S.E.2d 791, 792 (1981).Â  â€œHowever, this does not give the Court license to ignore facts unfavorable to that party.Â  In essence, we must determine whether a verdict for a party opposing the motion would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.â€Â  Id.
The Griffins do not dispute that Home Shop was not a party to the contract for sale or the installment sales contract between themselves and White Oak and McDonald.[1]Â  Because Home Shop was not a party to the contract, â€œit owed no duty or obligation thereunder.â€Â  Drafts v. Shull Sausage Co.,  276 S.C. 52, 54, 275 S.E.2d 577, 578 (1981); see also Roundtree Villas Assâ€™n, Inc. v. 4701 Kings Corp.,  282 S.C. 415, 423, 321 S.E.2d 46, 51 (1984) (finding the trial judge erred in failing to grant a directed verdict on a breach of warranty claim, even though warranties existed, because the appellants did not enter into any warranty agreements).
Rather, the Griffins assert that Home Shop should be held to a duty under the contract for sale because McDonald was acting as Home Shopâ€™s agent in connection with the sale.Â  We disagree.
Although McDonald may or may not have acted as an agent for Home Shop with respect to marketing the property, there is absolutely no evidence that McDonald acted as an agent for Home Shop in signing the sales contract.Â  See Frasier v. Palmetto Homes of Florence, Inc., 323 S.C. 240, 244, 473 S.E.2d 865, 867 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œA party asserting agency as a basis of liability must prove the existence of the agency, and the agency must be clearly established by the facts.â€).Â  
With respect to the contract for sale of the Crystal Drive property, McDonald signed the contract himself as seller and owner, on behalf of White Oak.Â  The Griffins never alleged that Home Shop was the actual owner or seller of the property.Â  The only potential agency relationship that could exist with respect to the Griffins breach of contract claim is the relationship between McDonald and White Oak.Â  See Peoples Federal Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n v. Myrtle Beach Golf & Yacht Club,  310 S.C. 132, 145-46, 425 S.E.2d 764, 773 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œAgency is a fiduciary relationship which results from the manifestation of consent by one person to another to be subject to the control of the other and to act on his behalf.â€).
As a result, the trial judge erred in denying Home Shopâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the Griffinsâ€™ breach of contract cause of action.[2]Â  
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The Griffins argue that Home Shopâ€™s argument is not preserved for appeal because although Home Shop argued that McDonald was not acting as its agent, it never argued that it was not a party to the contract for sale.Â  However, Home Shopâ€™s argument has consistently been that McDonald, not Home Shop, was the seller of the house and that McDonald did not act as an agent of Home Shop in the sale.Â  Simply because Home Shop has changed the specific terminology used in its argument on appeal does not mean the issue is not preserved.Â  See McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co.,  325 S.C. 327, 344, 479 S.E.2d 67, 75 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œ[An argument] should be sufficiently specific to bring into focus the precise nature of the [issue] so that it can be reasonably understood by the trial judge.â€).
[2] Home Shop also argues that the trial judge erred in assessing attorneyâ€™s fees against it because it was not a party to the contract.Â  We need not address this issue on appeal.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (finding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issues is dispositive).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
In the Interest Of:Â  S., Damion, A Juvenile under the Age of Seventeen,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Marion D. Myers, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-302
Heard February 8, 2005 â€“ Filed April 27, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Damion S. pled guilty in family court to first-degree burglary, safecracking, grand larceny, and two counts of second-degree burglary.Â  On appeal, he argues the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to accept the guilty pleas because the juvenile petitions were insufficient.Â  
We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State v. Gentry, Op. No. 25949 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 7, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 11 at 37) (holding circuit courts have subject matter jurisdiction to try criminal matters and questions of the insufficiency of an indictment not affecting the subject matter jurisdiction of the trial court may not be raised for the first time on appeal); In the Interest of Jason T., 340 S.C. 455, 531 S.E.2d 544 (Ct. App. 2000) (extending the same due process analysis to juvenile proceedings as apply to adult criminal defendants in general sessions court), overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, Op. No. 25949 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 7, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 11 at 37).Â  
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
